Of course, coming from a rural constituency that has been hit with five years of drought, I know just how welcome it has been for our farming constituencies. However, I know, and the farming constituencies know too, that we need a fair system and that where there has been an overpayment these moneys have to be recovered by the Commonwealth.

These changes really will mean that the recovery mechanisms that will be made available include deductions from future drought relief payments or deductions from social security payments. I think they certainly agree with that process. It is about a fair system and the farming constituency acknowledging that the government is trying to help by making these arrangements as flexible as possible in relation to the recovery of those overpayments.

The amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 will enable Australia to fulfil our obligations in respect of the agreement reached with New Zealand that food safety and food standards are equivalent between the two countries. The amendment will allow for the Governor‐General to make regulations that give exemptions from the Imported Food Control Act for certain foods of New Zealand origin. This means that for public health concerns those foods will be treated as if produced here and subject to point of sale rather than point of entry inspection. This amendment has no effect on Australia's quarantine requirements or practices.

There are also amendments in relation to the Moomba‐Sydney Pipeline Systems Act 1994, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Sea Installations Act 1987 and the Quarantine Act 1908. To refer to one other point raised by the member for Kalgoorlie in relation to the Sea Installations Act, he contended that the foreign ships participating on our coastal routes may be detrimental to our national interests.

Let me assure the member for Kalgoorlie that that is not the case. I think he will find that when we get more competition on sea routes around our nation we will have a far more competitive environment, one which is far more conducive to making sure that our industries in Australia are internationally competitive. It will mean that we will be able to make the most of the opportunities that present themselves in the international markets.

BREAK.PARA: I thank members from both sides of the House for their contribution to the debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2).
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

TITLE.XREF: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND SIMPLIFICATION MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Simplification Measures) Bill 1997 has two main elements. Firstly, it seeks to integrate into the social security system most child related payments to veterans' families. Secondly, it attempts to simplify the current rate calculation provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The plan to integrate into the social security system child related payments to service pensioners and income supplement recipients was announced in last year's federal budget. It seeks to ensure that from 1 January 1998 almost all child related payments will be the responsibility of the new Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, which is due to take over the payment role of the Department of Social Security from July.

The previous federal government inherited from the Fraser government a complex, poorly targeted and mean system of family payments. That system included family allowance, additional benefits for pensioners and beneficiaries, and the family income supplement for the working poor.

Under the families package, these separate child related payments have been integrated into a single family payments system that is targeted towards low‐ and middle‐income families. That recognises the additional costs of caring for older children or living in private rental accommodation. Just as importantly, the families package ensured that family payments to low‐income families were linked to a benchmark of adequacy that entailed indexation.

In 1993, the Social Security Act was amended to integrate child related payments to pensioners into the family payments system. This bill seeks to achieve the same outcome for veterans' families with dependent children. The aim is to enable social security officers to become more of a one‐stop shop for family payments, reducing the need for families to have dealings with separate agencies.

If handled effectively, such an objective has much to commend it. To achieve this outcome, and with one important qualification, this bill effectively transfers responsibility for child related payments to veterans' affairs income support recipients from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the social security family payments system.

To ensure that no family will be worse off financially as a result of the change, the bill includes an important savings provision. This provision preserves the payment by Veterans' Affairs of child related payments such as the dependent child add‐on, the pensioners full rent assistance, and the guardian allowance, where a pensioner or recipient would otherwise be disadvantaged by the transfer. The opposition welcomes this safety net provision, which ensures that there will be no losers from the measure.

The second major element of the bill seeks to simplify the present rate calculation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The two elements are linked because the transfer of child related payments to Social Security requires amendment of existing rate calculators. The current rate calculation provisions in the act extend to some 110 pages, and entail six separate rate calculators and nine separate method statements.
If you were to believe the title of the media release issued by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) on 27 March 1997, it is a case of the minister cleaning up his act!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—However, before the minister rests too heavily on his laurels, it should be noted that on the most optimistic assumptions this bill will probably reduce the 865‐page Veterans' Entitlements Act by a comparatively modest 80 pages. The minister's second reading speech indicates that this is the first instalment in a staggered review of the act to redraft it along `plain English' lines. The opposition supports such a redraft and seeks clarification from the government of the timetable and process that are to be applied to the project, and the resources devoted to it in an environment where the department's staff levels continue to fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the specifics of the rate calculators, there are at present six—one for each of the following categories: service pensioners with children; service pensioners without children; service pensioners who are blind; service pensioners on frozen rate; income support supplement recipients with children; and income support supplement recipients without children.

The bill seeks to replace these separate calculators with a single rate calculator, but one that contains seven modules and involves six overall rate calculation processes, all of which largely mirror the existing processes. This highlights the complexity of this crucial aspect of the legislation, resulting from incremental decisions that have been made over the years to make exceptions of certain situations. I well understand that in complex systems there often needs to be a trade‐off between the objectives of simplicity and clarity, on the one hand, and equity and fairness on the other. As a result of changes to the rate calculators, the bill also introduces consequent changes to the Aged Care Act 1997 and the Aged Care Income Testing Act. These are simply housekeeping changes that make no change to existing entitlements.

The opposition does not oppose the provisions of the bill dealing with the rate calculation process, but wishes to flag an anomaly or two that require attention by the government. A particular anomaly that has been brought to my attention by a range of veterans' groups concerns the impact of disability pension payments on rent assistance to service pensioners. This is something that is directly relevant to the rate calculation aspects of this bill.

There is bipartisan agreement that disability pensions, being compensation for war caused injury or illness, should not be counted as income for taxation or veterans' affairs pension purposes. The only exception to this at present is that, under the act, where a service pensioner also receives a disability pension, the rate of their disability pension reduces the rate of rent assistance payable. Where the pensioner is receiving a high percentage of disability compensation, this can completely extinguish their access to rent assistance. This provision appears to be a relic of an earlier period when rent assistance for pensioners was generally subject to a separate income test. Separate rent assistance income tests have been removed from all other parts of the social security and veterans' affairs systems, except for those in this situation.

Some may argue that people receiving both a service pension and a disability pension would be receiving an adequate total income and can therefore do without extra allowances like rent assistance. To me, the difficulty with this argument is that it means that a dual—that is, disability and service—pensioner living in private rental receives no more assistance than someone who is a home owner. After all the work produced by the national housing strategy and by other studies as part of the housing reform agenda, I would be surprised if any member would argue that private renters do not face particular financial difficulties, particularly in large cities such as Sydney, but elsewhere as well.

I would also point out that the returned service community rightly receives financial assistance from the government under the defence service homes scheme, in the form of a mortgage subsidy paid out of the Veterans' Affairs budget to Westpac, to assist them to become home owners. It is only right and proper that this should be so. To my mind, however, this subsidy only strengthens the argument that veterans who are struggling in the private rental market warrant extra assistance towards their housing costs, even where they receive a dual pension. I acknowledge that the situation I am raising has been in place for many years. Nevertheless, I believe the minister should try to address it when the opportunity arises. I doubt that the cost involved in disregarding disability pension income for rent assistance purposes would be particularly large. It has been suggested to me that it would cost about $9 million.

In conclusion, I mention in passing the opposition's strong concern at the impact on veterans of several measures in the recent budget. We will be taking the opportunity to highlight these concerns in future debates in this chamber and in the Senate. I indicate support for the current bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It always astonishes me that whenever the government does something good, the opposition gets up and says that it is not good enough. They never acknowledge the fact that we have only been in government for a short time and that, in that short time, a great deal has been achieved. Not many ministers have achieved as much as the honourable Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) who is in the Chamber today. The purpose of this bill, which is his bill, serves to finalise the amendments to the budget simplification bill 1997 to give effect to the coalition government's budget for Veterans' Affairs as contained in last year's budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of this bill is to facilitate the process for the income support recipients by having them dealing with only one Commonwealth department in order to establish their entitlements to child related payments as a result of the integration into the Department of Social Security's family payment of the child related payments made to Veterans' Affairs.

There will be no reduction to the total amount of Commonwealth payments made to the family unit and there will be absolutely no negative financial result on any income support pensioner or payee. The changes contained in this bill will go a long way to providing a plain English version of the Veterans' Entitlements Act and, through simplified rules that are easily comprehended by veterans and the community at large, the coalition government is delivering on our commitment to streamline public administration through a more efficient service delivery. This is pretty much a general housekeeping bill and I am pleased to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those members who have participated in the debate on this non‐controversial legislation and note the comments by the shadow spokesman on the other side of the House, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who has left the Main Committee. I thank him for his comments. I did listen to some areas where he said that we should be, where possible, seeking to amend some areas of the defence service home loans legislation whenever possible, but I remind him—as he would perhaps acknowledge in his own speech—that his party did have 13 years in government to make such changes—perhaps he ought to remind himself of that from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments will make one step closer a process for simplification of our Veterans' Entitlements Act. As was highlighted in some parts of members' speeches, 80 pages have disappeared, as a result of these amendments, from an 800‐page Veterans' Entitlements Act. So whilst this is the first tranche in the simplification of the act, I think that it is acknowledged by both sides of the parliament that it is probably long overdue.
I have amendments and I will foreshadow those amendments—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that you have an explanatory memorandum.

—Yes, but prior to introducing it I want to indicate that whilst we have our first tranche of the simplification of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the bill before the House does eliminate 80 pages. That is important and I can assure the opposition that we intend looking further at our Veterans' Entitlements Act in terms of simplification. It is in everyone's interest and, above all, it is in the interests of our veteran community. I present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 140, page 24 (line 23) omit "section", substitute "clause".
(2) Schedule 1, item 140, page 25 (line 3) omit "section", substitute "clause".
(3) Schedule 1, item 140, page 25 (line 27) omit "section", substitute "clause".
(4) Schedule 1, item 140, page 26 (after line 16), at the end of the item, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11 Saving provisions applicable to certain people who cease to be service pensioners on 1 January 1998

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to subclause (2), this clause applies to a person at a particular time (the relevant time ) if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a service pension is not payable to the person; and
(b) a service pension was payable to the person immediately before 1 January 1998 at a rate that included one or more pension child-related amounts in respect of a child or children; and

(c) a service pension would have been payable to the person at the relevant time at a rate that included one or more pension child-related amounts in respect of that child or those children if the amendments made by Schedule 1 to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Simplification Measures) Act 1997 had not been made.

PARA.TAB: (2) This clause ceases to apply to a person, and does not afterwards again apply to the person, if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the service pension referred to in paragraph (1)(c) would have ceased to be payable to the person; or

(b) family payment under the Social Security Act is no longer payable to the person or the person's partner or is no longer payable to the person or the person's partner at a rate higher than the minimum family payment rate; or
(c) service pension becomes payable to the person.

PARA.TAB: (3) A person to whom this clause applies is taken for the purposes of subsection 85(7) to be in receipt of a service pension under Part III.

TAB.TAB: pension child-related amount , at any relevant time, means an amount that would be required at that time to be included in a service pension under Module C or Module D (as Module C or Module D was affected by Module DAA) of the Service Pension Rate Calculator at the end of section 42 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 as in force immediately before 1 January 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: The first three amendments are minor corrections to the bill and have no policy implications. The fourth amendment is to protect another small group of veterans. These veterans would otherwise lose eligibility for full medical treatment benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, where their child related payments are integrated into the family payment. These veterans now receive a disability pension of 50 per cent or more of the general rate as well as a service pension. That combination of payments entitles them to a full range of medical treatment benefits from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The veterans targeted by this amendment are those who will not be paid a service pension after the child related payments are integrated. The amendments will ensure that their treatment entitlements remain for as long as they continue to be eligible for the above, the minimum family payment, for any child payable on 31 December this year.

The amendments, and indeed the whole of this bill, demonstrate once again this government's intention to look after the interests of veterans and their families while at the same time simplifying both the delivery of the Commonwealth services and the legislation providing for those services.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with amendments. The question now is that the bill be reported to the House with amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TITLE.XREF: INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TOURISM LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr McGauran:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset can I put in an apology in this debate for my friend and colleague, the shadow minister for science, the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans). Regrettably, he has come down ill this afternoon. He did want to make some comments in the course of the debate on the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill but, as I have suggested, he will be unable to do so. I indicate from the opposition's perspective, however, that we do not see any controversial elements contained in this bill, which at the end of the day simply changes in a whole variety of very minor ways the way in which this act operates. Accordingly, we will certainly not be opposing it and we do not, as I have said, suggest it is in any way controversial.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill seeks to amend a number of acts administered under the portfolio responsibility of industry, science and tourism. The Australian Science and Technology Council Act of 1978 is amended to add the council's functions and to reflect the addition of the term `engineering' to the name of the council. Appointments to this council will be made in future by the minister responsible, with the approval of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), rather than the Governor‐General.

The only thing I say about that is, of course, that we would like assurances, and I am sure the minister will be quite prepared to give them, that those appointments are from a carefully selected and culled group of individuals, that ministerial discretion reflects that the best possible people are appointed and that there are no other reasons why people should be appointed to that particular organisation.

I will come back to the tourist commission in a moment. The National Measurement Act of 1960 is similarly amended, requiring the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to maintain, or cause to be maintained, coordinated universal time as determined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures. The amendment will ensure that measurements are made on a consistent basis throughout the nation and are compatible with measurements in other countries. Again, this is a very sensible thing to do.

The Science and Industry Research Act 1949 is to be amended to remove section 9AB from the act consistent with the current restructuring of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985, the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Act 1992, the Patents, Trademarks, Designs and Copyright Act 1939, the Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989 and the Trade Marks Act 1995 are similarly to be amended to make a number of technical amendments in these pieces of legislation which are, again, non-controversial and therefore supported by the opposition.

The Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987 is to be amended to remove the requirement that the members of the board of the commission cease to hold office at the age of 65 and that the board not employ persons on terms and conditions more favourable than those of the managing director, and that is probably a very sensible thing to do. Finally, the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Act 1987 is to be repealed as it no longer has application.

As I have indicated, Mr Deputy Speaker, the opposition does not oppose any of this legislation. However, in connection with the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987, permit me to make some very brief comments generally about tourism which I seek your indulgence to do. In particular, what I am concerned about and what I think the Australian tourism industry is concerned about are the number of difficulties now being caused by some of the comments, some of the perceptions, and certainly by some of the newspaper reporting, of the activities of the One Nation Party and the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

A couple of weeks ago I was in Brisbane as part of my responsibility as the shadow minister for tourism and I met with a number of people from the Brisbane Chinese community. These were Hong Kong Chinese Australians and Taiwanese Chinese Australians and they raised with me their concerns—particularly from a tourism perspective—about the effect that the One Nation Party's philosophies, and the comments being peddled by the member for Oxley, were having on tourism.

They cited as an example the fact that something like 40 tours from Taiwan, with an average of about 30 people on each, had been cancelled. They said the reason advanced for those cancellations was that there was a perception in Taiwan that Australia was no longer a welcoming country, a welcoming destination. I think that is absolutely abhorrent.

Tourism is now our second, and very close to being our first, major source of export revenue. Even this government has recognised that it needs to put some of the money back into the ATC which it took out in last year's budget and so it has put another $5 million in the 1997‐98 budget. This is in recognition of the fact that we are finding that the damaging debate in this country, with its racist overtones, is damaging our tourism industry. That is just one example.

I therefore found it quite interesting that in the Sunday Telegraph, a Sydney newspaper, on 1 June this year, there was a comment piece by Sarah Harris under the heading of `Passing the tourist buck'. I thought it was absolutely fascinating to read this. As you are a regional member from Victoria, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, and I note also that there is a regional member from Queensland present, I think that this is an article to which your attention should be drawn.
It talked about the operation of a Victorian tourism proposal and it said:
In the northernmost tip of East Gippsland Shire there is a tiny community called Delegate River which—by virtue of the Victorian government's lack of appreciation—should rightfully belong to NSW.
We will not quibble about that. The article goes on to say:
It has a beauty so sharp that if God did not rest there on the seventh day, he must at least have dawdled a while to admire his handiwork.
Sarah Harris goes on to say:
Late last year, this community was buzzing with the prospect of the first of several convoys of visitors from Singapore.
But at the height of the so‐called race debate, the bookings were cancelled.
It has taken much work by local operators to rekindle the Singaporeans' interest.
This month, the Delegate River Tavern and Tranquil Valley Resort will accommodate at least 20 visitors from Singapore.
Their hostess, Val Savige, has already received plenty of well‐meaning—if mistaken—advice from local patrons.
"They will only eat raw fish,' warned one regular. "They don't like being touched on the head," advised another.
The colourful local bard, minus his two front teeth, has kindly offered to take them fishing.
They may also meet a man rumoured, in a passion of grief, to have consumed the ashes of his late wife, or be privileged enough to see a platypus playing in the creek below their cabins.
They may learn that Kentucky Fried Chicken is local parlance not for fast food but Department of Community Services officers who "take‐away kids".
But whatever their tourists do, they will experience the genuine warmth of a real Australian community populated by characters as endearing as they are individual.
This is the best antidote we've got to Pauline Hanson's venom.

I think that particular article demonstrated that in rural communities in Victoria—just as is the case in what are commonly described as popular tourist destinations in this country, like tropical Queensland, the Gold Coast, Sydney, and so on—some of the nonsense that has been peddled by people and has been reflected, regrettably, in newspapers in Asia is having a detrimental effect on the Australian tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the honourable member name the paper that that article was printed in and the date?

—It was the Sunday Telegraph of 1 June 1997, Mr Deputy Speaker. In concluding my remarks in this debate, I again want to make it perfectly clear to people in this country associated with the Australian Tourist Commission and the Australian tourism industry, and more generally to our colleagues on both sides of this parliament, that there are real and lasting factors that, regrettably, are going to be a great disadvantage to Australia's tourism industry in some of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate your latitude, Mr Deputy Speaker, in allowing me to make those comments in what is a very limited and technical bill. It was the first opportunity I have had and I felt that, given some of the things that have been happening in our country in the last few months, it was an appropriate comment to make. Let me reiterate that the opposition in no way believes that this legislation should be impeded and I wish it speedy passage through the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the confirmation by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), in leading for the opposition, that the opposition will not be opposing these amendments. As the member for Cunningham has just stated, the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is of a non‐controversial nature. It amends 10 acts administered in the industry, science and tourism portfolio: the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978, the National Measurement Act 1960, the Science and Industry Research Act 1949, the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987, the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Act 1987, the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985, the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Act 1992, the Patents, Trade Marks, Designs and Copyright Act 1939, the Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989 and the Trade Marks Act 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978 add the field of engineering to the council's increased responsibilities. Additionally, delays in appointments to the council will be greatly reduced by the direct appointment by the minister, with the approval of the Prime Minister, instead of the present system of referring appointments to the Governor‐General, with all of the delays that that has incurred.

All of the other amendments are straightforward and of a non‐controversial nature. However, I want to make passing reference to the repeal of two subsections of the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987—specifically subsection 14(3) and 42(3). The repeal of subsection 14(3) removes age restrictions to the continuation of appointment after the age of 65. The repeal of subsection 42(3) will allow those employed by the board, in particular those who are employed in overseas offices at sufficiently high remuneration to live in some high cost of living countries, to earn a higher salary and conditions than those of the Australian managing director, for all of the obvious reasons. I support the amendments.

This is a general housekeeping bill which is quite extensive, covering—as I said earlier—some 10 different acts. It is important to note that some of these acts go back to 1949; some, to 1960; some, to 1987; and some, to 1985. They have all been overtaken by certain—

TALK.START.PARA: —You might inform the Committee what those 10 acts are.

—Yes, I am glad of that interjection. I would speak on all of the 10 different acts. The procedures for making appointments to the council, as I said earlier, are very important in that the previous arrangement required the Governor‐General to make the appointment. As we know, the wheels of government turn slowly and the Governor‐General had to ensure that those nominated had the approval of the minister and of the Prime Minister. That caused a great deal of delay in the appointments. As a result, a great deal of time was wasted. This will now be taken away by the changes which will allow the minister, with the approval of the Prime Minister, to make the appointments.

BREAK.PARA: I am conscious of the fact that there is a great deal on the agenda this afternoon. Whilst in general terms this bill is of a non‐controversial nature and serves to close off some of the real loopholes—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member has done very well.
—I thank the honourable member for that interjection. I would restrict my comments now and just conclude by saying I strongly support the amendments to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I owe some appreciation to the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) for a very mild filibuster. The amendments in the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 are, in themselves, not important but they give me an opportunity to say something which I think is perhaps fundamental. The fact that they are brought together from various parts of legislation, affecting various areas of government responsibility but all coming under the minister for industry, is very pertinent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time we started to understand what we mean by industry and industry policy. Rod Cameron of ANOP made a very interesting speech last week to the minerals conference in Canberra, in which he pointed out that the current assessment that he has made of his own work and some work on behalf of the minerals industry suggests that people in Australia are extremely concerned about the perceived absence of industry policy. In the chamber, day after day we have been debating these questions about industry policy. It is important to start talking about what that actually means.

There are some who think industry policy is a way of giving cash or some handout to business. There are some who think that one writes a monumental manuscript of enormous length and detail, spelling out how every industry should work. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in some smart remark the other day, referred to a 10‐year plan. A lot of people feel that somehow there has to be a single, discrete thing: complex, detailed, and totally prescriptive. Perhaps one day it may be that; I have never known it to be.

Industry policy in a modern Western society is the accretion of a whole range of forces: many negative, many positive. It also involves a mind‐set and an understanding of what industry is actually about. The idea that taking away the regulations, taking away government and taking away so‐called red tape and letting business get on with being in business will somehow produce some coherence is—quite frankly—fanciful. The idea that out of chaos comes order is not very logical. An industry policy first requires an understanding of what the drivers are and what the forces at work are. The forces include competition, government, cost, innovation, commitment, and an understanding of how the bits fit together—how the ingredients actually work together.

BREAK.PARA: When one looks at the effect on investment of, say, depreciation and then starts to hear how Treasury for so long has talked about depreciation as being a form of business welfare, one can start to see why this country might have a problem. That problem arises from the fact that people deal with the fragments discretely on one hand and yet they talk about them as if they are coherent, and on the other hand the alternative they argue for is a prescriptive, detailed and punitive system.
What this government fails to understand, and what it is doing at the moment—and has been since March last year—is making and carrying out industry policy. The fact that it has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am having some difficulty in following the member's contribution on this debate, which is a very narrow one particularly relating to repeal of subsections in tourism legislation and changes to bounties. It is probably not appropriate for a wide ranging debate on industry policy as such. I ask that the member contains his remarks to a more narrow focus on this particular legislation.

—The point that I am trying to make to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that this is industry policy being made right now in narrow, prescriptive, detailed little ways across four or five pieces of legislation which in fact project and give an attitude and affect things. For the last 15 months the government has been changing bits and pieces all the way through—or doing nothing at all. That, in itself, is making policy. That in effect is actually doing something.

BREAK.PARA: I am suggesting that what these amendments to the legislation indicate is of no great consequence. The fact is that they have been brought forward in bits and pieces, in dribs and drabs and fragments all over the landscape; the whole industry and commercial landscape is littered with bits and pieces. Whether they be computer bounties, shipbuilding bounties, or R&D tax write‐offs, they are bits and pieces which are, in fact, making a substantial policy change to this country. More importantly, they are making a substantial change to the attitudes and mind‐set of the people out there, both in the community and in business.

So the government, in effect, is making policy even by these minor technical amendments. I urge the House, and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to understand the significance of what is actually happening in this period. The decision of the government that it will not have an industry policy per se means that the industry position you have is an unconscious and fragmented one that is failing. If people in the community think that there is no industry policy and the people in business think that there is no industry policy, then a country without industry policy obviously does not want industries.

So what the government in effect is doing through this process is dismantling what was a reasonably healthy attitude towards industry on all sides—by the work force, the employment community and the investment community. I am trying to put on notice that this House, this parliament and this government will some day have to face up to the fact that this is not the way to approach issues; this is not the way to run things. It is not appropriate to bring together five or six technical amendments and say that these are inconsequential and we do not discuss and debate them, so that the country and industry are run step by step, brick by brick, tile by tile, across some mosaic of which no‐one can see the picture in advance and no‐one can see it afterwards. You are building a picture with mosaics. These little pieces are changing the landscape. They are changing the scene and no‐one knows how, least of all the government.

My concern is that that approach is doing this country great damage and I think that if you ask your community you will find that people will say the same. If you ask your business people about their confidence in this government's industry policy or in its approach to industry you will find the same conclusion. This is not the way to run a country and it is not the way to run industry policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am having great difficulty with the member's contribution because the amendments, in fact, clarify the commencement dates in an act and do no more than that. I think the member really should contain his remarks to the bill before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the point I am trying to make is that, if one confines one's remarks to what comes forward in each tiny fragment of legislation from the government, we would never discuss anything. These amendments are to the point, but I have concluded my remarks anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to be able to sum up this legislation on behalf of the government and to thank all the members who contributed in one way or another. We have heard wide ranging speeches touching on a number of topics, thanks to the tolerance shown by the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: As all members know, the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 amends a number of acts administered by the portfolio of industry, science and tourism. As has been acknowledged by one speaker after another, the changes are not controversial and are mostly technical in nature.

Several of the proposed amendments implement important election commitments given by the government in the area of science, engineering and technology. For example, we have maintained our commitment before the last election to change the name of the Australian Science and Technology Council to become the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council—a very important and symbolic change which has been welcomed by the Institution of Engineers and by the engineering community in general. The Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council is a very significant source of independent advice on science, engineering and technology policy. The amendments to the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978 implement this important name change.

The government has also sought to implement a number of changes to improve the effectiveness of the CSIRO, consistent with our recognition of that research body having a leading role in Australia's technology and industry development. Overcoming structural impediments to focus on key research products was a primary concern. Changes proposed to the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 reflect the new administrative framework developed by the review of CSIRO's management structure and performance, and put in place the government's objective to facilitate greater flexibility in CSIRO's structures and research programs. I am glad to say that that new structure is working particularly well.
The remaining amendments are largely administrative in nature and, as such, do not raise substantive issues. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Ruddock:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of telling comments in the Spicer review into the migration agents registration scheme. One key finding says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the absence of regulation, the market for migration advice has tended to operate imperfectly with consumers bearing unacceptable cost in terms of exploitation and inappropriate practice by a sector of the industry; . . .
More importantly, another key finding says:

. . . that the Scheme has provided a measure of consumer protection and . . . its credibility as a consumer protection mechanism has strengthened somewhat in the time since the Joint Standing Committee on Migration (JSCM) conducted a review of the Scheme; . . .
Essentially, there is an admission out there that this is one industry that needs a significant amount of regulation.

I would be the first to admit that the organisation that, in the long term, the government sees as having some role in self‐regulation—the Migration Institute of Australia—is a reasonably reputable association. It has structured meetings with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs three times a year; it has conducted training courses; it was involved in the Roach inquiry; and, indeed, it is an organisation that we do not have too many criticisms of. It has even received grants from the government to develop a practical training course.

The reality, as the other part of the quote says, is that there is an industry here in which we see very desperate people and we see some very crude sharks in the market who very much are on the ball essentially to exploit these people, whether by claiming refugee status when they have got no bona fides in the world, by launching spouse or de facto relationships when people have not even got the required cohabitation, by having people already in bigamous relations purporting to remarry et cetera—you go along the train of claims. Many times it is essentially aimed at buying time in Australia, once they come here and overstay, to develop a relationship with somebody during their period of fighting this refugee claim.

I want to say, on the other hand, that, whilst there is a need to supervise those kinds of operators in this industry, the reality of life is that you often have people in your electorate, constituents, who have been just as involved in this conspiracy. They want to buy time, they want to rort the Australian system and they are out here to overstay.

The inquiry, titled Protecting the vulnerable, by a joint committee of which the current minister was a member, came down in favour of a number of recommendations. They included the continuation of the then scheme for three years, a review at the end of that period, continued registration of lawyers—which was a fairly controversial measure and which was upheld in the courts of this country, despite the views of lawyers—individuals not being required to register if they worked for voluntary organisations and training modules for migration agents.

It also suggested something which this government should do, and which was suggested to the previous government; and that is to close the longstanding loophole that advice to sponsors and nominators is not covered by the provisions of legislation. As I say, it should have been undertaken by the previous government and it is more than necessary to be undertaken today because it is a major loophole where those who are in malpractice in this field ignore the needs.

That unanimous inquiry, which wrote to all 1,450 then registered agents, received 65 submissions, had witnesses from major sectors of the industry, such as the department, the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales, immigration advice centres, the Law Council, the Migration Agents Registration Board and so on, and came to a number of conclusions. Amongst them were the following:

The principal issue is not whether the advice is paid for or is provided free of charge, but whether consumers, particularly those who are least able to shop around for advice, should be able to expect accurate advice from competent advisers, and whether they should be able to access appropriate avenues of redress should the advice which is provided prove to be negligent, inaccurate or dishonest.
The committee furthermore, at XXVI, noted:
One particularly invidious outcome—
and I have just mentioned it—
of the omission—
that is, of nominators and sponsors—
is that persons who have been found to be unqualified or unfit to practise as migration agents can circumvent the scheme by directing their practice through sponsors.
The parliamentary committee furthermore noted at 2.20, on page 9:

In addition to the above, many requests for immigration advice arise from persons who are not in a position to advance adequately their own cases or the cases of family members. Applicants may lack an adequate command of English, or may not comprehend the requirements for making immigration applications. Such applicants may be unable or unclear about how to best advance their cases. Applicants from different cultural backgrounds might not understand the processes and the statutory requirements relating to visa applications.
At 3.82 the committee came to a unanimous summary of the then prevailing situation in the industry and in the regulation of those agents. It noted at page 61:

Statistics obtained by the Committee support a finding that achievements of the Scheme relevant to its objectives have been chequered. On the positive side, around 600 persons either have been denied the right to practise as migration agents or have decided to withdraw from seeking entry to the industry. In addition, the avenues for developing expertise in migration law have increased noticeably, with various courses and seminars now being conducted at a tertiary level and within the industry itself. On the negative side, disciplinary action taken against migration agents has been minimal, even though the number of complaints in relation to registered and unregistered practice has been increasing over time.

I want to put on the record at this stage that that is certainly a very clear weakness of the current scheme. There are doubts out there as to the way in which people can be pursued and, I guess, an unwillingness by many people exploited to come forward because of the reality of their situation. I have got to express some early doubts that self‐regulation is going to essentially do anything about that aspect—the most significant aspect of the problem.

We might be able to bemoan the question of cost to the users in the field, we might be able to make a number of other criticisms of the scheme as it currently operates but, fundamentally, I believe the most important aspect of this is to rid the industry of these people, dissuade them from participation and, whether people like to hear this or not, penalise them and throw them out of the industry if necessary. I do not think that that most crucial aspect of the problem that the committee itself noted is going to be tackled by self‐regulation.

BREAK.PARA: There is an admission by the Spicer inquiry—and this is why we have got a situation here today where the legislation is being extended until next year—that the industry's main organisation, which I have earlier indicated is one which we can largely have respect for, is not in a situation where it can claim to be representative of the industry. Its membership is rather small. I think the last figure was 2,200 people registered. There are some major players that are members of the Migration Institute of Australia. There is talk about banks, even voluntary organisations and corporations, and there are probably some practices in this field which are members, but a significant part of the industry is not involved in the institute.

The Spicer inquiry says that at this stage it is incapable of policing the industry. That is why the government speaks about the concept of statutory self‐regulation as an interim measure in their move towards self‐regulation. The minister notes agreement with this analysis of where they are at but, on our side of the debate, we do not have the confidence that he has that the ability might be there within the next six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next six months is for the—

—Sorry, 20 years time, is it? The minister is conceding that they are, as he says, incapable at this stage of conducting self‐regulation—and I take his point. The situation, as the Spicer inquiry noted, is such that there are quite a few remaining problems in the field. As a person who has consistently questioned the degree of influence of various lobby groups on our migration policy, I want to say that I think we went to the other extreme in the Spicer inquiry. I notice that one of the members of the inquiry had some involvement with Careforce, but I thought the balance was too far in the other direction if we look at the membership; it had a significant preponderance of practitioners. At the end of the day, regardless of one's analysis of them as individuals, you would have to ask whether there was a degree of self‐interest in moving the government out of the field, moving the administration out of the field and thrusting towards self‐regulation.

BREAK.PARA: I am not saying for a moment that there are particular errors or particular weaknesses in the inquiry but, as I say, I think I have a reasonable track record in not wanting these kinds of organisations to be dominated by FECCA or by some immigration advice centre. But, if one were to analyse the make‐up, one would perhaps say it had swung too far in another direction. The inquiry did make a few pertinent points that are important for the future, regardless of whether there is support eventually for self‐regulation. I think its point No. 11, on page 5, is accurate and should be taken on board regardless of the direction this country goes in. It notes:
. . . there has been inadequate promotion of the current Scheme and, in whatever arrangement replaces the current Scheme—
or, for that matter, if the current scheme continues—
an ongoing consumer information strategy, targeted in particular to members of non‐English speaking background communities, needs to be developed.

That is indicative of what I said earlier. I think there is a lack of knowledge out there of what to do if people feel that they have been ripped off or even if the people they go to feel ripped off. There is a lack of knowledge and a lack of confidence perhaps that, at the end of the road, they will be getting success in pursuing people.
The Spicer inquiry also noted:

that in a deregulated environment, consumers in the migration advice industry would not be able to rely solely on the remedies available to them under consumer protection legislation and have in fact failed to take action to any significant extent either in the courts under the consumer protection provisions of trade practices legislation or in the States and Territories small claims tribunals.

So they are putting on the record something that is in evidence: that there is a relative lack of successful prosecutions, and many people—as we noted earlier—have been dissuaded from moving into the industry. But that does not mean that there are still not a number of people who perhaps, with more knowledge in the field and with more determination, might have been pursued.

We have concerns that with a reduction in the support of various advice centres by the government in the 1996 budget, these people that we are supposedly trying to tackle and supervise and to rid ourselves and the industry of, are going to be encouraged. There is no doubt that the significant reduction in support by the government of people who are doing this kind of assistance on a voluntary basis only opens up the field in a more obvious way to those who wish to exploit people.

The legislation, as on a previous occasion, is an extension by this government of the currently operating provisions. And I want to mention again that unanimous report, Protecting the vulnerable? which made a number of significant suggestions as to the better operation of the supervisory section of the industry. Some of those suggestions were not taken up by the previous government; others which were taken up, in the view of the Spicer inquiry, essentially improved the situation.

The summary position is that we do have here a field that allows people who have come from societies where there are repressive regimes lacking the rule of law, where people have no knowledge of the court system, where they have fears of police and of police institutions, to feel more confident. We are saying to these people that they should know their rights straightaway. They should know that they have to be very thorough in the way they deal with people offering advice to them.

That is not the reality that people have out there. They are extremely desperate on many occasions and see their only option as being the person they have been led to by family or friends or, more often, that person who advertises very heavily in particular ethnic media and who sometimes has the support of institutions within the ethnic community as being their basic salvation and way of staying in this country. They are, as the opposition notes, very vulnerable and they should be our primary responsibility and we should not adopt an attitude as to how we should regulate this industry on the basis of ideological bent. We should have doubts about an industry which, at this stage at least, in the view of the Spicer inquiry is not capable of operating without very major improvement. It should get more people involved, have more membership, and reach a stage when it really can say that it represents the industry. Until that happens, I think that we have really got to question whether the next stage of this process is in the interests of those people that we say are most vulnerable. One of the recommendations of the Spicer review stated:
. . . in the interests of developing a cohesive industry with consistent standards, mandatory registration as migration agents continue to apply to legal practitioners.
That is an important point that the joint committee in its past review strongly supported, regardless of their feelings of self‐importance and their desire not to be covered by regulation.

The other point that the opposition would have some concerns about is the resourcing of this regulation. It is not just a question of eventually handing it over and being hopeful that things will basically scrabble through and that they will be able to do it through their own resources. The opposition supports the extension of the current legislation, believing that, on balance, it has had major accomplishments, that it has kept a lot of people out of the industry who should not have been in it in the first place.

The legislation has had some measure of supervisory oversight so that perhaps people will be more reluctant to exploit others. It has probably accomplished that in the area of fears about moving the charges too heavily. It has, in some cases, removed people from the industry and essentially, at the end of the day, it has a motivation which is beyond the self‐interest of those people who seek—supposedly in the long‐term—to regulate themselves. I commend the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 provides for a six‐month extension to the migration agents registration scheme under the Migration Act 1958, given that the present six‐month sunset clause would see the scheme terminate on 21 September this year. Extending the scheme to 21 March 1998 will initially allow for the introduction of statutory self‐regulation as a transition stage before the eventual introduction of full self‐regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Institute of Australia, a relatively new industry body, will have time to establish the necessary structures to take on this self‐regulatory role of over 2,200 migration agents now operating. Disciplinary sanctions including removal of the right to practise are expected to form part of the industry based self‐regulation. There will also be specific complaints resolution processes to protect vulnerable members of our community and aspirant members who use migration agents.

The government's plan to move progressively from the current scheme to partial supervised deregulation and eventually to industry self‐regulation will enable the government to support and work with reputable agents and allow this peak body to develop standards and self‐regulatory systems and procedures, picking up on the comments of the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson).

Two years ago, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in its report Protecting the vulnerable? delivered some mixed findings on the operation of the scheme which had only been established in September 1992. When the then government introduced the scheme, they rejected self‐regulation because of a claimed high level of fragmentation in the industry. The creation of an industry peak body since then is an important step in ensuring that migration agents are more able to speak with one voice.

I found it interesting that the joint standing committee's report suggested that it was difficult to determine just how many visa applicants sought the advice of migration agents. An Immigration Rights and Advice Centre telephone survey suggested that three per cent of callers specifically sought guidance on alleged wrong advice or the checking of other advice from migration agents. However, the complexity of migration legislation and regulation, the extent to which people compete for places, and an applicant's inability to advance their own or their family's case are other factors pushing them towards migration agents.

The joint standing committee criticised the generally low level of public awareness of the scheme, as has been mentioned by the member for Reid. The scheme has also not fulfilled its aim of becoming self‐funding. On a more positive note, the committee noted that 600 people had been stopped from practising as migration agents. This demonstrates that the provision of migration advice is an imperfect market and that the current regulatory system still enabled shonks to get a foothold in some cases. The then Refugee Review Tribunal commented that `many agents are ignorant of the regulations' and that `submissions are little more than legal nonsense.' The Immigration Review Tribunal commented that in 1993‐94 the proportion of successful applicants was the same, whether or not a professional adviser was used.

The self‐regulatory regime will bring forward the self‐interest of reputable agents to ensure that vulnerable potential migrants are not exposed to incompetence, dishonest and exploitative practices from people offering migration advice to the discredit of legitimate, competent and qualified professionals working in the field. Last time I spoke on this subject, I suggested that migration agents were people who were proffers of hope. They sold the hope and the prospects of coming to our country as a key ware that they had to offer for their payments. That just highlights the importance of protecting people who turn to these advisers in the hope that they will improve their prospects and chances of migrating to our great country.

The proposed changes in the bill follow an internal review by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The task force took advice from a group of independent experts chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, former chair of the Australian Chamber of Commerce.

One recent example brought to my attention is of a visitor to Australia who liked the place so much he wanted to stay. He must have been visiting the electorate of Dunkley; it is a wonderful place. A migration adviser in a regional centre, which I will not mention—not far from Dunkley—advised him to apply as a refugee. He said that he was not a refugee in any sense of the word, but he followed the advice he had been provided for his $3,000. Clearly, he was rejected and now forfeits any credibility when applying in the future on more legitimate grounds. I cannot begin to tell you how much he laments taking the advice that was offered to him.

It also leads to the question of lawyers, and I am pleased to see that lawyers are being brought within the scope of the program. It is not a question about whether they are charging more than $1.20 per photocopy page or those sorts of things. It is an important specialist area where very much they are providing advice on hope. Just as migration agents need to ensure that they understand the program, so must lawyers.

Going back to that earlier comment, pure legal nonsense is not a way of getting through the system, notwithstanding the considerable sums of money that are often paid for very poor advice. I am sure the member for Reid and other colleagues in the committee room are aware of the number of people coming into electorate offices all around the country looking for help after they have paid good money to migration agents only to find that they have sent them up the wrong track.

I am very encouraged by what the minister is doing and I would like to pick up on some of the points that the member for Reid has mentioned. We seem to be in heated agreement over this. We seem to agree that there are doubts over whether the present system as it is is working effectively. We share that view, and we also share the view that the current system has been inadequately promoted and that there is a lack of knowledge about it.

Unlike the member for Reid, I do not believe there are doubts over self‐regulation at this time because of the way the minister is going about this particular transition. What he is saying in the first instance is, `We'll supervise a partial self‐regulation, where the minister can delegate the authorities to the institute, and see how it goes.' We can learn from the experience. The minister is there to provide advice and support over time as the institute—again as the member for Reid says—develops and matures and gets up to speed to be a fully competent peak body for the industry.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting that the member for Reid referred to some papers on the free advice that is provided to people seeking to migrate to Australia. My view is that, wherever you are getting your advice from, the consumer still deserves protection. I certainly would encourage the minister and the institute to consider including voluntary organisation in the work of the institute as we move into this partial self‐regulation regime.

The reason I say that is that I have many people coming to my electorate office seeking our assistance after they have spoken with an ethnic community organisation outlining perhaps how they should go about seeking to apply to enter our country. Often that advice is not accurate. Often that advice has led to people from my part of the world being very up‐beat and very positive about their prospects without really seeing how they measure up against the criteria of the migration program.

In some way, I would certainly encourage the minister to ask the Migration Institute of Australia to take in some of those organisations, both in the development phase of the systems and procedures that it is putting in place in preparation for self‐regulation and also to see whether there is a way of ensuring that those community organisations, and others offering free advice—out of goodwill more than anything—are at least fully informed of what is going on and are not providing false hope to people.

It also would ensure that the consumers that we are seeking to protect can be involved in the development of those systems and procedures as, once again referring to the member for Reid's comments, the institute gets up to speed in preparation for self‐regulation.

I will not add a lot more than that, although I did have some rather interesting facts on the changes that the government has made to the migration program, why I believe the changes are very much for the better, and why I believe the measures the government has put in place have built confidence in the migration program and, to some degree, have made it a little more complex, thereby increasing the need for competent advice to people wishing to apply.

In closing, it is clear to me from reading this report and from my very vague understanding of the career of the member for Reid in this place that he has something to offer. I certainly encourage him to put forward his ideas and to make a positive contribution to what the minister is trying to achieve. He should let the Australian public and aspiring Australians benefit from the obvious understanding and insight he has on this subject. The opportunity is there in this supervised delegated regime that the minister is overseeing to ensure that the particular systems and processes, the checks and balances that need to be put in place, are developed and are in place as we move towards industry self‐regulation.

I commend the bill to the House, congratulate the minister on his continuing good work in a difficult place, and invite my colleagues on both sides of the House—including the boisterous member for Reid—to make a contribution where possible to the development of a self‐regulatory system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 extends to 21 March 1998 the sunset clause of the migration agents registration scheme, which was to terminate on 21 September 1997 after having operated for five years. It is for that reason that the opposition supports this bill, and for that reason only.

SPEECH.PARA: This move is in preparation, from the government's point of view, for statutory self‐regulation for a transitional period, with a proposed move to full self‐regulation of the migration agents industry. My view of self‐regulation can sometimes be characterised as giving the blood bank to Dracula to look after. Unfortunately, Australia has seen some disappointing results from self‐regulation.

The opposition recognises the limitations that exist in a globalised market whereby migration agents who operate solely offshore are not subject to regulation in the same way that Australian‐operating migrant agents are. However, we also need to recognise the inherent contradictions and limitations that self‐regulation imposes, particularly in a market that even Mr Spicer has described as less than perfect.

Mr Spicer is not known, from my experience, as someone who is an ardent opponent of self‐regulation—indeed, he has often been at the forefront of running arguments supporting self‐regulation. In this instance, he is encouraging us to be fairly cautious, and I think that is the prudent course for those who support self‐regulation.

For my part, I have some very serious concerns about the proponents of self‐regulation in this industry in particular. For instance, the government has articulated concerns about the potential for abuse of the spouse provisions of the migration regulations. In fact, these concerns have been cited as justification for cuts to the migration program.

This bill raises questions about how, at the end of the day, the government will be able to control the level of fraud in the marriage program, for example. If the government is really serious about stopping fraud in the marriage categories of the migration program, it would need to ensure that the method of regulation—self‐regulation or otherwise—is effective, not only on the fraud issue but—and from my point of view this is a more important issue—the level of the exploitation of the applicants involved.

One view is that, because of the complexity of migration law, it is unrealistic not to give applicants the ability to obtain professional advice about how to maximise their chances of lodging a successful migration application. The previous speaker suggested that voluntary organisations should be included in the scope of the current debate, but the facts of life are that they are already covered by the scope of the current regime.

They already have competency standards and they compare very favourably with private providers. However, in the absence of adequate funding being provided so that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs can perform that function—and I note that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has sustained pretty tough cuts this round—the government needs to ensure that whatever regulatory regime is imposed or is adopted, whether it is self‐regulation or otherwise, is effective.

This arises essentially out of the complexity of migration law. We have accepted in this debate, prima facie, that migration law has to be complex and we have then progressed down the road about how migration advice may be provided. I suggest there is another course which bears some thought and that is the degree of complexity that migration law actually requires.

The cost of migration applications is very high. There is the cost of applications, and a person may require further advice about migration law from migration agents. We need to really ensure that people are getting value for money in terms of accurate and lawful advice from migration agents and that that advice is fair dinkum. More importantly, we need to ensure that people who apply for migration to Australia do not have their expectations falsely raised about their chances of lodging a successful application, bearing in mind that this is an industry where people make profits out of other people's hopes and expectations.

BREAK.PARA: I have heard stories recounted today, which are consistent with this line of argument, of examples of genuine asylum seekers to this country who provide vast sums of money to agents in order to lodge applications for refugee status. Many of these people appear to have been told by unscrupulous agents that their claims will have a greater chance of success if they enter Australia through the back door, that is, come to Australia as a tourist and then lodge a claim for refugee status whilst in Australia.

Someone who is desperate to escape an oppressive regime does not always have the time or inclination, capacity or resources, to sit down with immigration officials to determine the best way of proceeding. In these cases we need to ensure that asylum seekers do not arrive with false expectations of their claims being recognised simply because they have been encouraged to put up a large sum of money.

Members might remember that I spoke yesterday of the problems encountered by workers on the Mandir Society's temple which was opened in Canberra last weekend. I commented in the media last Sunday on this situation where workers are brought into the country and their rights as workers are breached. In that instance the workers were paid an appalling rate of 51c an hour, contrary to the undertakings that the sponsor made to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. They were not paid superannuation, they were not paid proper allowances, they had inadequate safety protection, there was inadequate fall protection, if any, and there were no first aid kits on site, and so on and so on.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs was advised, but the sponsor was able to bring out more workers. The department allowed this circumstance to take place even though it knew that this blatant exploitation was taking place. Clearly, there needs to be a little bit more guts applied in some of these circumstances.

I do not know whether, in that particular case, the workers were brought out through a migration agent, but that is not the point. There have been documented cases of people who have been brought out and basically their rights have been totally ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you first raise that? Was it yesterday?
—I will take that up with you after I have finished my speech, if that is all right with you.
—Yes, because I would rather you continue with the bill before the committee.
—That matter has been raised with you by the CFMEU over a period of time going back about 12 months. Whilst it is not likely—
—Can I say, not in specific terms.
—Order! Minister, you will have a right in your winding up to comment on the member's speech.

—Whilst it is not likely that these people are brought in by accredited migration agents, or by anyone who would seek the status of an accredited agent, we need to ensure that the body which governs migration agents is able to deal with these cases if they come to its attention by way of referral to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, or other law enforcement agencies as appropriate, and that those agents are resourced sufficiently to protect those people who are some of the most vulnerable.

BREAK.PARA: Whatever scheme is ultimately adopted by the government, whether it be self‐regulation or an enhancement of the current system, it is proper that we do improve the game. There is a general consensus that the current system needs to be improved, but there is perhaps a divergence of opinion about how that might be done. I am concerned to ensure that the move to self‐regulation, if it does occur, does not undo the good work that has been done so far.

In conclusion, the opposition supports the continuation of the current program, which is why we are supporting this bill. In terms of the debate about the progress to self‐regulation, I think there are a number of matters and issues that still need to be resolved. A very prudent, cautious and conservative approach needs to be taken. I am pleased that the general recognition for prudence and caution has been echoed on both sides of politics. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am pleased to have this opportunity to sum up in relation to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997. I thank the members for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), Dunkley (Mr Billson) and Fraser (Mr Dargavel) for their comments. As the member for Reid has left, I will come back to his remarks. I will pick up those of the honourable member for Fraser instead, in case he intends to leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with the issue on which I interjected, because it is a very important question. I am sorry if I missed some remarks you made yesterday in relation to this matter. It is the usual practice, if you wish ministers to be aware of your remarks, to indicate—perhaps by a call to the office—that you intend to raise something and then they might be in a position to follow it up quickly with you. Being now apprised of your remarks, I will have a look at the question.

Let me also say that I have spoken with the construction union on a number of occasions during my consultations. While general issues have been raised with me about the need for efficacy in processing skilled applicants, either through employer nomination or under the other alternative arrangements which we have where there are tripartite labour market agreements for people to be able to enter Australia to work in particular situations, I understand the union's reticence and desire to protect conditions and so on.

We are not about using the migration program as a basis for undermining conditions here in Australia. All I would say is that at no point in time was I aware of the particular claims that you have raised in relation to the temple development here in Canberra. I do not recall that matter having ever been brought to my attention and, I suspect, if it had been, it would have been something that I would have noted.

I simply make the point that my department is in a position to act in relation to visas granted on particular conditions, if we are apprised of the fact that breaches are occurring. There are certain natural justice provisions that have to be followed, and you do need to put before people the assertions that are made; and people need to stand up and say that somebody is not being properly paid, so that we can put those matters properly before them and deal with them.

The reason that we have to follow that course is very simple: it is because of the administrative law that operates in this country. In relation to the rights that people obtain through the issue of a visa, we are not in a position to simply terminate the visa without following the natural justice principles of putting allegations that are made before people, for them to have an opportunity to correct them if an error has been made.

That brings me to the second point of substance in the honourable member's contribution that I wanted to pick up, and that was in relation to the complexity of the migration act and regulations. I do not think it is generally understood why we have an act that is so complex and so difficult—

TALK.START.PARA: —So they can let you manage it, Minister.

—It gives me an advantage over many. I at least have some element of understanding of it. I do not know that that is necessarily desirable—not that I should have an understanding but that I should be the only one who understands it. I have an understanding of how this arose under your predecessors. Senator Ray was the person who essentially got in place the present act and regulatory regime. This was modified through the reform act that followed.

SPEECH.PARA: We moved to introduce the statutory scheme that we have in place today because we had seen develop over time a situation where the previous largely discretionary regime was no longer capable of operating in this area. This was largely because of the operations of administrative law. The courts had essentially taken over the determination as to who was going to enter Australia and who was not.

I frequently draw to people's attention and put before them an interesting article written by a former immigration official, Evan Arthur. He made it clear that we were going to have 14,000 onshore applications on strong and compelling compassionate grounds under the guidelines that have been developed for interpreting that provision, which was section 6A(1)(e) of the old migration act, by the courts when the matter was largely left for them to define what those words meant.

The former government was not of the view that the immigration program should be dominated by people who had entered Australia on the pretext of being a visitor, simply managed to run a reasonably good story and then been able to stay in Australia. The view was that if people wanted to apply to come here they should apply offshore and wait their turn.
