Ultimately the statutory regime we had with the very limited discretion that ministers now have—the non‐compellable discretion—was to ensure that the government of the day was able to administer the program as it had planned.

You made some observations about asylum seekers. I would like to say that it is a vexed issue about which I could speak at length. I am certainly concerned to contain the abuse that is occurring in relation to asylum claims but I do so in the context of a determination to ensure that no bona fide refugee should be rejected. I recognise that some people's circumstances might be such that they will go to extraordinary lengths to get here. They will pay people. They will forge documents. They will mislead me as to their intentions. But it is because of their vulnerable situation and the claims have to be examined on that basis. That is the obligation we have accepted. My officials understand that and that is why we provide the opportunity for review independently by the Refugee Review Tribunal.

I challenge the members of the Labor Party in relation to some of the proposed changes that I will be initiating during the course of these parliamentary sittings in relation to the issue of judicial review. We have already a very significant litigious load. I am probably the most sued minister of the Commonwealth at the present time. There was an expectation that when we put in place independent merits review that people would get out of the courts. It has not happened.

The fact that the courts are involved has led to significant changes in the way in which people are able to enter Australia. It has removed a lot of the decision making from the government of the day. I will be proposing a mechanism whereby we can again get control of the immigration program for the parliament and for the government of the day.

That will be done through a privative clause which will ensure that the only matter that the courts will be able to examine is whether or not the people who take the decisions—at first instance, my department and the merits review system that we have in place—are legally competent to take the decision. That will considerably narrow the range of issues that we take into the courts and upon which the courts can turn their very creative minds. It will lead to a situation where the act may not have to go through the many contortions that it now goes through to deal with some of the very elaborate approaches that are taken by the courts in dealing with this act in particular cases.

To come back to the bill that we are dealing with, the bill is to extend the sunset clause. If the sunset clause is not extended, the present statutory scheme collapses. Let us understand it—it collapses and then there will be no scheme. We are proposing an alternative; one that has been developed as a result of a review undertaken by my department; one that was the subject of advice from a reference group of very eminent Australians.

I accept the comment of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) that Ian Spicer was a person who normally would be a gung‐ho deregulator. He was a member of the reference group. Other members of the group included Pamela O'Neil, a former member of the Labor Party and a very distinguished agent for the Commonwealth in a variety of roles; Ian Tonking, a Sydney barrister and a specialist in trade practices matters, particularly in relation to consumer affairs issues; and Cheryl Webster.

The member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) asked some questions about Cheryl Webster. I have known Cheryl over a long period of time. She works as a grant‐in‐aid worker for Careforce, which is part of the Anglican Home Mission. I do not think that in any way disqualifies her. Madam Deputy Speaker, the Anglican Home Mission society has worked amongst migrants and refugees in your electorate over a long period of time. Cheryl is a person of great personal quality and one who can contribute and did contribute significantly in relation to this.

The other members of the group are John Hodges, a former minister, and Pauline Matthewson, a prominent member of the Migration Institute of Australia. It was a very balanced group and its advice was very helpful. It was not an ideological issue. It was a matter of addressing the work of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

The honourable member for Reid took us through the committee's report very helpfully, but I remind the member that I was on that committee and I am very much aware of its recommendations. The committee was of the view that self‐regulation should be looked at. The reason that there was a sunset clause and it was continued was that this was an option that was always to be kept open.

The committee recommended in 1995 that the migration agents registration scheme should continue to operate for another three years with a range of improvements, and that at that stage it should be reviewed so we could look at these further models. Self‐regulation was one of those that was held out. We are operating largely within that time frame.

It is important to recognise that what we are proposing is a form of regulatory self‐regulation. In other words, there will be amendments to the act to establish that the Migration Institute is the body that will be undertaking the supervisory role. It will be in accordance with its code of ethics. It will administer a scheme in which peer pressure will establish, hopefully, the highest order of supervision and standards for membership.

I think those people who are ethical and who are involved in the Migration Institute will be anxious to ensure that the higher standards are upheld. My expectation is that they will work with legal practitioners. They have already indicated to me that they will sit down with the Law Council to look at ways and means of integrating their different approaches to the question of supervision. I expect that they will be able to work together in the way in which this particular scheme is developed.

I thank particularly my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) for his very supportive observations. I think they were far too generous, and I speak with a degree of experience in relation to that. I know my own weaknesses but I nevertheless thank him for it. Let me say that voluntary organisations will be included in the regime. We fund a number of organisations now for the purposes of providing advice, and that is important. We expect that those people who are offering free advice through voluntary agencies ought to be the subject of supervisory arrangements. They will still be able to be registered. They will not have to pay a fee and they will not have to necessarily satisfy the same comprehensive knowledge test.

One of the things that I am very supportive of is the work that is undertaken through our universities and through a number of the voluntary organisations that we fund to provide tuition, if one might put it in that form, for people who want to be migration agents. We have a number of programs now that are leading to a better trained work force in this area. That applies not only to agents but to the legal profession. It is an area of some complexity and difficulty, and one where specialisation is very important today.

I thank honourable members for their support for this legislation. Obviously, my officials and I will take on board all of the comments that have been made. We are in the process of drafting the legislation now and obviously there may be a much more comprehensive and vigorous debate when we see the substantive legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my earlier contribution, I remind those present that I spoke glowingly in support of the Child Support Agency Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I spoke about it as being a humanising and responsive change so that people's real lives could be better integrated with the systems and procedures of the Child Support Agency. This is achieved by providing an opportunity for income estimate elections to better reflect the non‐custodial parent's capacity to pay and, as a result, to reduce the likelihood of custodial parents having to refund overpayments. It will reward reliable payers of child support by allowing for their employers not to be involved in the arrangements where they have a satisfactory track record of paying. It also provides for the Family Court to take into account private arrangements amicably entered into when making property and spousal maintenance orders.

SPEECH.PARA: I spoke about the bill as being a welcome first step in ensuring that the law supports and encourages the sort of desirable behaviour we hope for where a relationship is no longer viable and there are children left behind who need to be cared for. I mentioned a number of further reforms that I believe warrant consideration, and I sought to encourage the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) to constructively contribute to the diligent work that many of us in this place, under the chairmanship of the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), are doing in trying to deal with many of the challenges facing the community, involving relationship breakdown and the care of kids.

I say to those opposite: resist the temptation to be petty and pathetic as the coalition government seeks to deal with the recommendations that remain from the joint select committee report on the child support scheme and other, quite numerous, constructive ideas that have been brought forward by the coalition members working in conjunction with the member for Grey.I say that for the kids' sake. This is about making sure that the kids get the support, care and input from willing parents towards their development into young Australians and great citizens of this nation.

There are a number of things which I mentioned in my earlier contribution that simply seek to ensure that the system encourages all parents to do the right thing and to reward them for it, and to discourage behaviour that is unhelpful or contrary to the care and development needs of the child. That is one of the great dilemmas that I have with some of the provisions and arrangements that the Child Support Agency operates under at this time: they seem to actually discourage people from doing the right thing.

The person sitting in your chair on the last occasion I spoke, Madam Deputy Speaker, allowed me to use the term `the stuff it option'. That is what far too many of my constituents say to me when they come to see me, in despair about the impact that the Child Support Agency regime is having on their lives. Too many people are saying that it is easier just to throw their job in and not put in to the community but to put in to their own care needs and, as a result, not to provide anything in the way of financial assistance for the care of the children that they helped to create. It is disastrous that people are seeing that as a viable alternative to being a constructive and willing contributor to the development of their children.

We should view the Child Support Agency in the first instance as a fallback option where less intrusive and light‐handed regimes are applied to people who voluntarily go about doing the right things out of interest and care for the child. The Child Support Agency arrangements need to be interventionist, intrusive and quite prescriptive for people who are not doing the right thing. But to apply those sorts of regimes to people who are doing the right thing is a very sad mistake.

BREAK.PARA: In closing, there are some issues that I would certainly encourage those in this place to consider. The first is to foster greater cooperation between the Child Support Agency and the Family Court. I spoke briefly about it in my last contribution, and I encourage all of us here to put our minds to that. The second is to try to work out a way of encouraging non‐custodial parents to go that extra yard to do the overtime or take on that second job, to try and repair their lives at the same time as making a contribution towards the care of their child. How can we do that? There are some good ideas around and we need to work through them.

I welcome the interest of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in this matter. I am certainly encouraged by the vast number of coalition members that are very serious about trying to leave an improved Child Support Agency as a memento of our first term in government. I commend this bill to the House and I ask those present, when they are thinking about the Child Support Agency, to think about changes that are there for the sake of the kids.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) with his well‐chosen comments on what has been a long running issue for the parliament and, indeed, for the nation. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 has been in the parliament for some time. It was introduced into the House on 6 March 1997 and referred to the Main Committee on 18 March 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the legislation is, firstly, that custodial parents will not have to refund overpayments but, instead, future payments for the year will be reduced commensurately; secondly, that non‐custodial parents will be able to make their payments directly to the CSA, rather than through an employer; and, thirdly, that the Family Court, when making property or maintenance decisions, will be able to take into account future liabilities under the Child Support Act, even if an assessment has not been made.

No doubt the details have been well canvassed previously in the debate. I will not go over old ground, but I will pick up some of the points that the member for Dunkley has made. There is a great challenge for the parliament to improve the child support scheme. It is not just about the administration of the CSA, because that is symptomatic of a deeper issue, in my opinion.

The child support scheme has a history of at least two decades. It goes back to the changes to the Family Law Act of Attorney‐General Murphy in the Whitlam era, right through to the mid‐ to late‐1980s, when the child support scheme was introduced with the Child Support Agency. Although the Child Support Agency has seen a doubling of the number of parents who are contributing to the care of their children—that is, from about 30 to 35 per cent to about 70 per cent—that still leaves 30 per cent of parents who are not fulfilling their responsibilities to care for their children. So there is much work left to be done.

The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues has been well quoted over the last 2½ years that it has been before the parliament. Many of its recommendations have been introduced, but there is still much work left to be done. The underlying philosophical base whereby parents have the responsibility to care for their young—in the case of the child support scheme, to the age of 18—is at the heart of this issue. The tendency not to rely sufficiently on private arrangements, as they have become known, and the tendency for the DSS to refer people readily to the CSA seem to be issues which the parliament should consider.

It is pleasing to see that the member for Chifley (Mr Price) has introduced a private member's bill. I know of his deep interest in this matter and of the commitment that he, as chairman of the joint select committee, and those across the parliament made from about 1994 onwards. I am sure that the response that they received from the public and the work that went into it must have left an overwhelming impression on those members.

The member for Chifley continues his long‐running interest in this issue. I remember him commenting to me—and I am sure he would not mind me saying it—that too much of the focus of the child support scheme is on the corpses of dead relationships. That was a profound comment that I will never forget. The need to look forward from those failed relationships, certainly those that have children resulting from them and yet do not survive, is a key issue for the new government. That is, the new family, whatever its format, has to be considered as much as those children who remain in the previous family.

The child support scheme has great difficulties, I believe, in that it falls within at least three portfolios: Social Security, Assistant Treasurer and Attorney‐General. It is quite a job to try and bring those portfolios together to focus on this issue. There has been well‐documented, or at least well‐discussed, opposition from within the public sector and from within areas of the Department of Social Security to any change, because they believe that they have got a formula that works. Certainly it has worked somewhat better than the system in the old Family Court days. But in the opinion of many, as the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) has mentioned, and certainly from the government side and from the back bench, there is a view that it should work a lot better. There is plenty of potential for it to show great improvement.

The issues of inconsistent advice from the CSA still are constantly surfacing. There is a range of issues that I do not think I will canvass here tonight, but that the committee I have the good fortune, or otherwise, to convene is in the process of discussing. What we need to realise is that this is not a gender issue. This is an issue about fairness for families. It is an issue about the private responsibilities of parents. For it to become some kind of gender contest defeats the whole notion of the responsibility of the adult community to children.

In conclusion, I do not think this is an issue that we can afford to allow to become a partisan contest. It is essential that all parents take their responsibilities to their children with the utmost care—and that, I am sure, the overwhelming majority do. The responsibility of the government is to support the principle of supporting those parents who put their children as their number one responsibility. It is not prudent for any government to have a situation where the social welfare system, the court system, or any other system undermines that fundamental responsibility of parents to their children.

When you consider that we have gone from virtually zero employees employed by the Child Support Agency to about 2,400 people, at a cost to the taxpayer of something approaching $130 million for an agency that has the role of saying that parent A shall pay parent B for the care of their children, you have to ask the fundamental question of whether the pendulum has swung too far. The bipartisan acceptance of this legislation is one more small step in the improvement of the child support scheme. However, there is much to be done and I look forward to playing my part in that. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. Since the establishment of the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency in two stages—firstly, in June 1988 and, secondly, in October 1989—the results have been mixed with many cases bordering on frustration at a time when emotions run very high. The issue of child support is one of particular interest to me because of the large number of constituents in the Petrie electorate who have had a marriage break‐up and who are directly involved in a case in the Child Support Agency or are affected through independent maintenance payments.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most frustrating things that I find in my dealings with constituents and the Child Support Agency is that every case is so very different. Every case deals with people who have emotions, who have different needs and different circumstances, and they need to be looked at on their individual merits. The Child Support Agency seems to have a number of loopholes which have led to great consternation and distraction in the maintenance settlements. It is important that we, as a government, take the time and effort which is necessary to sew up these loopholes.

We need to listen to our constituents on these issues and we need to work through the problems for the betterment of the whole community at large. A point that needs to be made when we are dealing with the child support scheme is that each case can be terribly time consuming. As I have mentioned, the issues are complex and like any situation there are always two sides to a story.

The child support scheme deals with the rights of the child. The rights of a child should always be foremost and we need to look at that very carefully. The belief is that when children are involved in their parents' divorce the children must be protected, and they must have a sustainable, great quality of life.

I expect that all members of parliament in their day‐to‐day dealings with constituents would receive similar complaints on this issue. The main areas of concern for people tend to be on issues such as custodial parents not receiving maintenance, and repetitive or conflicting letters received by the paying parent. Many constituents have also raised with me the complexities and the concerns relating to the percentage system in deducting the level of child support to be paid.

While I acknowledge that in any system that exists there will always be people who are trying to find holes or ways around it, there seems to be, in the case of child support, plenty of community discontent and a strong push for change in this area. I believe it is important to acknowledge, on behalf of all the people in Australia who are affected by this, that there are a number of huge concerns with the Child Support Agency.

As a member of the government, I believe that amendments to the legislation are absolutely necessary to assist custodial and non‐custodial parents and must be given absolute priority at this time. We must look at flexible legislation being introduced into this House that tries to amend some of the inequities which presently exist and look at ways to ensure that the system works well and works with people instead of against those whom it was originally intended to assist.

The system must work for both parents. It must work towards providing an amicable and timely maintenance delivery as well. It must work for custodial and non‐custodial parents in such a way that the administrative procedures do not supersede positive results. The government is aware of some of these problems with the child support scheme and, as the previous speaker, the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) mentioned, it is working towards that. I am happy to say that I am a member of the committee looking at reviewing this legislation and it is looking at some of the ways that we can fix some of the problems of the past. The child support legislation amendment presently before the House addresses a number of discrepancies, many of which arose from the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, which was also mentioned by the member for Grey.

BREAK.PARA: In the time available to me tonight I want to speak to a number of these amendments. Firstly, I wish to make a couple of points in relation to the amendment dealing with the consideration of child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings. This amendment has important ramifications for those parents who voluntarily pay maintenance as presently the Family Court does not take this into consideration when making property and spousal arrangement judgments.

There have been many who have felt that the system has failed them because property arrangements have not been taken into account when child maintenance payments were made, or that future circumstances were not taken into account. In essence, as a result of the amendments, custodial and non-custodial parents who have private arrangements will be treated exactly the same as those parents working under the guidelines as specified in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. This amendment ensures far more flexibility. Maintenance cases can involve property trusts and other assets, and the level of child support should be taken into account in those proceedings.

The amendment also gives some forward thinking to the legislation. The legislation will now take into account private arrangements for child support and give opportunities to take into account potential liabilities under the child support scheme.

A further amendment deals with employers who withhold child support from an employee's pay packet. I note that, according to the explanatory memorandum for the bill, nearly 30 per cent of those who pay child support have arranged their circumstances such that the payments are withheld by their employer. This amendment adjusts this situation and gives the option for far more flexibility for those who wish to pay child support straight to the registry.

Through this amendment the payer of child support will have far more independence, and the intrusiveness which they may have felt in the past will be diminished. In some cases the employee may not wish the employer to know of their previous personal history. Administration, paperwork, and compliance costs to employers are also expected to be reduced by this move.

However, I do acknowledge that there are cases where the payer may default in payments. The amendment covers these instances with a trigger mechanism which results in the employer withholding the relevant amount of child support in those cases. Those who default will cause employers to withhold payments and they will have very limited future access to this procedure.

The legislation also allows for payers to appeal if their application to pay directly is rejected by the Child Support Agency. A further advantage of this would be to reduce the cost to employers of administering the child support payment from their employees' wages. Most businesses do not object to complying with this but they do object to the terrible impost placed on them.

A small business operator recently contacted me detailing the cost to him of collecting child support on behalf of the Australian Taxation Office. It was absolutely horrendous. The administrative costs included cheques, bank charges, stationery, postage and computer processing. For this particular company, when all those costs were taken into account, it amounted to $12.36 per week per employee, which totals $642.72 per year.Just imagine the enormous savings that can be made to private enterprise, and to the government as an employer, if those who pay child support can opt to make their own arrangements.

There are a number of other amendments in the bill also in reference to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 which bring them into line with references to the Social Security Act 1991. These are necessary for continuity and consistency. On the whole, the legislation acts as the first step in the federal government's process of reviewing the whole child support scheme.

I am sure that both sides of the House can support this process to streamline the child support legislation. I believe it is really important that we have support on both sides for this legislation and that we work towards ensuring the benefits for both parties involved. The Child Support Act does have problems and there are some great concerns out there, but this government is making a major commitment to fix those problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend taking up too much time, because what I have to say and the sentiments that I have about the child support scheme have been expressed by those who have already spoken in the debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that over 80,000 Australians have signed petitions pertaining to child support and the Family Law Act is indicative of the animosity in the community in relation to both these laws. Of all the issues brought to my attention by my constituents, there is none more voluminous, and none which causes more emotion and grief, than that dealing with child support and family law. I am certainly not envious of the minister responsible for the Child Support Act, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). To have responsibility for that and for superannuation is a double‐whammy poisoned chalice, if I can put it that way.

The bill being debated makes changes to certain aspects of the child support scheme. The objective of child support is certainly justified, as we have all noted. The child support scheme came into effect in 1988 with the objective of requiring both custodial and non‐custodial parents to pay for the maintenance of their children rather than leave it to the taxpayers—who are, too often, expected to provide for all the needs of so many people in our community.

While the objective is certainly worthy, to put that objective into legislation is a difficult task by any means, as we have discovered over the years. There is no way that, on issues such as child support and family law, any parliament would be able to provide legislation which is suitable to all people. Nevertheless, as a member of parliament, you do hear of cases which make you wonder how our laws allow to take place certain practices that, at the end of the day, ultimately affect not the parents but the child, who is always the innocent victim in such disputes—although that point is quickly forgotten.

The first change provided by the bill allows a non‐custodial parent to seek a revision of their payments owing, if they believe their income is less than 15 per cent of the previous year's income. This will, of course, amend the non‐custodial parent's child support assessment. If a custodial parent has received an overpayment, this bill will allow them to receive reduced payments accordingly until the ledger is balanced, so to speak, rather than having to pay back the overpayment.

One child support case that I had brought to my attention dealt with the matter of a non‐custodial parent overpaying the custodial parent. Apparently the Child Support Agency wrote to the gentleman offering three options: reducing payments until the overpayment was offset; taking a payment from the CSA of the equivalent of the overpayment; or giving the payment to the custodial parent as a gift. I thought that final option was a misnomer, given that the parents obviously had irreconcilable differences which had brought them to the situation that they were in. As such, it was not surprising that the non‐custodial parent did not take up the final option.

While this amendment is welcomed, it will still leave many clients of the Child Support Agency quite dissatisfied. The theme of many complaints to my office is in relation to the assessments made by the CSA, and the fact that the information used for the decisions affecting their assessments does not reflect the actual situation that the non‐custodial parent is in. People ask me why, when they are earning X amount of dollars, the CSA assesses them as though they are earning Z amount of dollars. I hope that this amendment will provide the relief that those people require who are earning less than they are assessed as earning, notwithstanding their obligations to their child or children. That is the paramount point. I only say that because I know that I will still have people coming to my office complaining about their assessments and the facts and figures used to calculate them.

The second change effected by the bill is to allow non‐custodial parents to make their payments direct to the Child Support Agency rather than have them deducted from their pay and forwarded to the CSA by their employer. This move is consistent with other legislation that has come before the House, such as the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill which allowed the parent's child‐care payments to be paid directly to the child‐care provider. This reduces the intrusiveness into what is essentially a private matter between family members.

If the non‐custodial parent chooses, there is no need to require the employer to deduct pay from a non‐custodial parent for forwarding to the CSA. The previous situation implied that the non‐custodial parent could not be trusted to make payments to the CSA and that the payments should be compulsorily deducted from their pay beforehand. This is a logical amendment that I am sure non‐custodial parents will find completely welcome. They know that they have a responsibility for the upkeep of their children, and the vast majority will not shirk their responsibility and will continue making their payments personally, without the intrusion of a third party.

My principal concern is that the CSA pass the payments on punctually, which is but another topic of complaint that I receive about this particular subject. The final change deals with potential child support liabilities when the Family Court is making decisions on property or maintenance. In closing, I would like to read to you a letter which I received on 29 May, which is so typical of letters that I receive concerning this particular subject. Obviously, I will leave my constituent's name private. The letter reads:
I am writing to ask you to raise the issue of child maintenance in parliament, specifically to amend the laws of the Child Support Agency.
Before I begin let me state that I want to support my family and I know it is right that I should do so.

My situation and many others I have spoken to about this subject is: I earn around about $30,000 a year working from about 80 to 100 hours a fortnight; I am living in a rented duplex, I drive a 30 year old car and I'm BROKE. Though I live a mangy, pitiful existence I am expending a little more every fortnight than my net income; and you know what the means.

After accounting my expenditure which includes just normal everyday bills with the exception of tithing I pay to my church—which is tax deductible—I am left with about $3000 for the year for buying clothes, entertainment, birthday/Christmas presents for the kids and the mother/wife, little luxuries like haircuts and medication which cost me about $300 to $400 a year and a variety of miscellaneous things. I have a personal loan for a computer which is $70 a fortnight, the rest as I have said is just living costs.

I dream of one day buying a house and starting my life again. I would like to buy another car to replace the one that is breaking up around me. If I found another companion I would like to be able to keep her. I would like to think that I am getting ahead and moving forward and maybe having the benefit of joying in some little reward that I can give myself for supporting my family and paying my taxes and doing the right thing. But in sad reality, I can not. And the cruel hard fact of the matter is, I never can. If I work overtime or work myself to near death with one or two other jobs to get ahead then bang, I am hit with a greater child support bill the year after.

Most importantly is my relationship with my children. I have lost the benefit of watching my children grow up and having them around me as a family. Now it's twice a fortnight I have my kids sleep over. I would like to be in a position to compensate for my separation from the children, on the days that I see them by taking them out and spending a little money on them and supporting them directly instead of indirectly. When my rostered days off come around and I have my kids over I have very little money to do anything but feed them.

This situation leaves people to either give up to the extent they want to give up; Go on the dole; Earn undeclared cash money or turn to criminal activities to get ahead. This I cannot do and why should I have to resort to immoral or illegal activities to live?
If I cannot afford to pay petrol or maintenance costs for my vehicle then I have no alternative but to cease work.

Or if the physiological impact of being separated from the family, working in a stressful job and then having nothing to show for it but the worry of mounting bills, poverty and bankruptcy; if this anxiety and sorrow causes a break down then, what is the advantage in this? I would cease paying tax; The government would be obliged to pay my sickness/unemployment benefits and completely supporting my wife and kids.
Isn't it better that I am working and paying tax and willing to help support my children?
Now in the name of equality I would like to mention my wife and her charmed life. She is buying a house
in a suburb of Perth—

she drives around in a late model van, it appears that she can buy clothes for herself and go out whenever she wills, and she has the added benefit of having the children with her and buying things for them and taking them out etc, which I think is great; I am happy for her and I am grateful the kids have a good home to live in and a loving mother to look after them. My humble prayer is not to have what she has but at least have half the benefits and joys and opportunities that she has. At the moment I have zilch, zero, naught, nothing. The simple fact of the matter is, it isn't fair.
So for this reason I would like the child support laws changed . . .
He goes on to say:

. . . I'll leave it with you in the hope that you maybe able to do something to address the gross inequalities, burden and distress child support indirectly fosters amongst the many Australians whose only crime is, is that they for one reason or another, could not live with their companions.
Faithfully yours.

I think that letter just about says it all. Whilst I have no hesitation in supporting this bill, I do not think it will stop the tide of complaints that we all have coming into our offices concerning child support. As I said at the beginning of my speech, over 80,000 people have signed petitions airing grievances about child support and family laws. That displays the inadequacies of the legislation, although I do not intend for that to imply blame. I simply do not believe one will ever be able to write legislation that pleases everyone in these disputes.

Given the dissatisfaction with these laws, minor amendments will not, in my view, stop the tide of complaints. Indeed, it has almost become a tidal wave of complaints and I have no doubt that the day will come when completely new legislation will need to be drafted replacing both the Child Support Act and the Family Law Act. I do not see why that should be later rather than sooner. I think the new laws should be on the agenda of all political parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to have an audience of such size for this debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill. This is a very tough area; there are no easy answers here. There is an interaction between family law issues with issues involving access to children, property law and so on. There are people who deny this but these issues are certainly not separate in the minds of those who are affected. I want to take this opportunity to put forward an idea which I have had in mind for some time in relation to property settlements. I would be interested in parliamentary and public reaction.

SPEECH.PARA: Family law is presently extremely costly, both to public legal aid and private legal parties. Many of the outcomes are not well regarded by the parties who are involved with them and a lot of them have a poisonous effect on interpersonal relationships. I think we need to look at codifying property settlements so that people know exactly where they stand so that there is no need to litigate.

I am interested in a system analogous to what happens with wills where the government regards as legally enforceable any agreement concerning property division in the event of separation or divorce made either before marriage or during marriage. However, in the absence of any such agreement we would have all property split fifty‐fifty in the event of a marriage breakdown, without regard to the issue of contribution or who has custody of the children and so on.

I am also interested in the idea of an opt‐out provision concerning child support whereby both parents would be given the option of assuming up to 50 per cent of the responsibility for maintenance of their children. If they agree to accept 50 per cent responsibility, the Child Support Agency would not be involved in that particular family circumstance. Of course, if they did not want to do that then the child support arrangements would apply. There has been a lot of debate about legal aid cuts in the context of the Commonwealth budget. It has a massive family law budget—I think, in excess of $100 million—and it does seem to me that we ought to be able to do a lot better than we are doing.

The second thing I want to do is pay tribute to the work done by the member for Chifley, (Mr Price), in this area. Child support is a work in progress and it is remarkable to see the extent of the praise coming to the member for Chifley from both sides of the chamber. So much so that I think it is worth drawing attention to some of the specific references. The member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) pointed out that the member for Chifley headed up the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, and also pointed out that this committee broke the record for the number of submissions received by a joint select committee or a standing committee on any issue being investigated. He said that the member for Chifley did a very good job with his committee. That has been said by other speakers in this debate, and I am sure it will be said throughout the debate. Indeed, the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said:
I think that the Price report did a good job. I believe that we should be looking more closely at that report and doing more in this regard.
The member for Bowman (Mrs West) said:
My congratulations go to the member for Chifley (Mr Price) on the Price report. He did an excellent job. It is now up to the government to put these recommendations into place.
Then later we find the member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) saying:

I would simply like to conclude by saying that many excellent recommendations have been made in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Matters, and I believe that they do need to be addressed.
We also had the member for Canning (Mrs Johnston) saying:

Before I start, I would like to commend the work that has been done by the member for Chifley (Mr Price). Not only is he very passionate about what he is doing, but he has also put a lot of work into it in previous years, and I congratulate him for it.

None of those members are Labor members. There are Labor members who supported the work of the member for Chifley, such as the member for Isaacs (Mr Wilton). But I think it reflects a remarkable degree of support for his conscientiousness and basic sense of fairness and decency on these issues, and I personally start with a presumption that his views in this area ought to be accorded a great deal of weight.

The third thing that I wish to do is to support the amendments moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) concerning the bill before the parliament. I think these amendments are worth repeating. The member for Werriwa has moved that the House:

(1) expresses concern at the failure of the Howard Government, after 12 months in office, to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues, entitled `Child Support Scheme: An Examination of the Operation and Effectiveness of the Scheme';
(2) believes the Government should be concerned about the well‐being and welfare of all families: whether they be intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families;
(3) notes with concern the failure to implement some of the report's recommendations has caused parents and their children to suffer needless hardship;
(4) believes that there is important and urgent need to improve and strengthen the Child Support Scheme; and

(5) considers that much time has been lost and therefore the Government should respond to the recommendations of the report concerned with changing the child support formula as soon as possible and introduce legislation within six months to this effect.
This is an issue about which massive community concern has been expressed. That has been noted by previous speakers from all sides.
I will just note a couple of the observations of the member for Calare (Mr Andren) who said:

By far the most angry and disgruntled group of people are the men who have lost custody of their children and have also lost out or come out with a lesser share in the divorce settlement. They are now paying substantial amounts of income in child support. In many cases their former wives have now found new partners and so have an extra income coming in. The way men see it, they have lost their wife, their house and their kids, and are now continuing to lose a large slice of their income.

Similarly, the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) reported to the parliament on a national conference on family law issues held by the Lone Fathers Association. He noted a set of groups which attended this conference, including DADS, the Child Support Action Group, GRANS, the Family Law Reform Party, Non Custodial Parents, New South Wales Family Law Reform, Parents Without Partners, and others as well. It is an extraordinary flowering of groups, if you like.

We are not a nation of joiners. To have so many groups which have arisen to try and address some of the issues in this area does suggest that it is an area of substantial concern. I have had the same sort of feedback in my own electorate. The previous speaker, the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) referred to cases and correspondence which he had received. I have received a number of similar letters, including one from a woman whose husband was previously married. She and her husband have one child.

She went through the child support formula and said that, from her point of view, the two children of her husband's first marriage were being regarded as more valuable than children that she has with this man. She regards that as a most unfair situation. When she challenged this, she said, `We were told by the Child Support Agency that disregarded income levels for custodial parents are as high as they are to encourage them to work.' Her observation is that since the child support becomes so large, why in fact would they work?

BREAK.PARA: In this particular case, the husband had been staying home to look after the child—and, in this day and age, a lot of people would regard it as very appropriate and quite reasonable for husbands to stay at home and look after their children. As a result, he was not earning any income. His former wife challenged the idea that he was not earning any income under ground 8 of the grounds of application. It says:
The income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of one of the parents or the child are not properly reflected in the assessment.

I have to say that, when I look at that ground, it seems to me to be extraordinarily open‐ended and to give the child support review officers an extraordinary amount of discretion. In fact, in this case, the assessment was made that the husband was able to provide child support, notwithstanding that he did not have an income. In the report of this case, the review officer said:
I note that the Payer's new wife is therefore able to work full time to support the family.

What is clearly going on here is that the husband's income is not being taken into account but his wife's income is being taken into account. This seems to me to be an unusual state of affairs and one which certainly can give rise to anomalies. We do receive correspondence of this kind.

There was another letter from a person in New South Wales who, I assume, wrote to all members of parliament. In his case, he said that the amount being deducted by the Child Support Agency was close to five times in excess of the amount that he had agreed on with his ex‐wife. Initially, she agreed to refund the excess amount that came to her but, after the payments started, she was not interested in doing so. In his letter he says:
I do not understand how the government can say that the more money I earn, the more my children cost to raise.

This is reflective of the substantial community concern that has arisen in this area. These issues are reflected in the statements made by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) when he put forward the opposition's amendment. In so doing, he expressed concern that the government, after 12 months in office, had failed to respond to the basic findings and recommendations of the parliamentary report of 1994 and that delay was occurring in addressing these issues. He pointed out that this committee had received something like 6,200 submissions, the largest number of submissions ever received by any committee of this parliament. The member for Werriwa also made some important comments about some of the fundamental concepts at stake here. He said:
As is so often the case with these win‐lose scenarios, the child support area has been seen through the prism of gender equity issues.
He also said:

It is also much healthier for the parliament and parliamentarians to consider child support through the prism of income equity concerns and to examine the fairness of the existing income transfers implicit in the formula.
He went on to say:
We should blindfold ourselves to whether the parent is male or female, and rather take an income equity focus on these questions.
He further said:
. . . by blindfolding ourselves to the gender equity concerns, the parliament can have a far healthier and productive debate.

That is an accurate way to look at these issues and to try to deal with them conceptually. I have a couple of additional remarks that I would like to make before concluding. One is that the member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) referred to the idea of linking child support and access issues. I have to say that the law to date, or certainly in recent times, has regarded these as entirely distinct issues and has not been willing to see it that way.

I do think, having spoken to quite a few parents who have been on the sharp end of the child support and access issues, that there is something in what the member for Dawson is saying, because you do get a situation where, if access orders are being flouted, the non-custodial parent is required to go to court himself or herself to seek court orders. There is always the onus of time, energy and expense resting on them, whereas, if a child support order is flouted, you have the full majesty of the Taxation Office and the Child Support Agency coming down on the person in breach of the child support order. It does seem to me that consideration ought to be given to some linkage or to at least developing a situation where those issues are dealt with in a more comparable way.

Finally, I think that family law and child support issues are a work in progress. My ideas on this issue are developing, as I believe that all of our ideas need to develop, in the light of experience. But the case for some action now is indeed overwhelming and government legislation, which picks up only some of the Price committee recommendations, simply does not go far enough. I do not think it is good enough for coalition members, pre-election, to be picking up votes by bagging the Child Support Agency and child support arrangements. It is now up to coalition members to actually do something about it. Supporting or taking on board the amendments proposed by the member for Werriwa would be a very good place to start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to represent the numerous paying parents in the seat of Lindsay who have come to see me over the last 14 months regarding the efficacy of the child support legislation. It is interesting to note, in any discussion on this subject, the actual history of child support and the Family Law Act.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Family Law Act was first introduced in 1975, it was only a small act of about one centimetre in thickness. It was designed to simplify the whole family law relationship and to move away from the concept of fault in any relationship breakdown. That act is now a three-volume practice manual of about 10 inches in thickness. The Child Support Agency Act was introduced in 1988.

By now, we are well away from the concept of fault. We are well down the track where there is an accepted community morality about the obligations to pay child support. Yet there are parties leaving a marital break‐up who feel like criminals. The intrusion into their personal affairs has been to such an extent that they have felt hounded. They have often given up jobs, given up employment prospects and moved into a cash society to avoid moral obligations or social obligations. This act goes some way to mending their feelings in terms of being able to hide from employers the fact that they have had a marital bust-up or that they are in fact experiencing some personal problems.

I think that is an important olive branch to offer in the family law disputes that do take place in today's society. It is something that this society is going to have to deal with and deal with in a very humane fashion, because more and more marriages are breaking up and more and more families are now second or third families. It is those people in those relationships that need to be considered. Gone are the days where people will break up after a 20‐ or 30-year marriage when no more children will be forthcoming.

BREAK.PARA: These days, you will find that, quite frequently, there are three or four children—all under the age of 15—from different parents, and all liable to be attracting child support. When you have 27 per cent of your gross wage going towards paying for two children from a previous marriage, you are probably paying 47 per cent in tax, and you are left with 26 per cent of your wage for your second family, which may have up to three children and a dependent spouse, you start to get very concerned about the efficaciousness of this legislation. It has resulted in an inordinate number of complaints.

By reducing the intrusiveness on people's subsequent lives when they move on from a marital break‐up, when they move into further relationships, when they move into further employment prospects, they feel that it gives them a chance to mend old wounds. It gives them a chance to move on and develop a better working relationship with their previous spouse.

That is crucial for the forward progress of this society. We need to achieve the original objectives of the Family Law Act 1975. We need to get to the stage where these matters are resolved by the couple on a basis that each feels has dealt with their needs. They need to feel that they have been fairly dealt with. They need to have a basis for continuing with their current and future living arrangements, and for continually changing.

The adversarial system—the number of complaints and the number of political organisations that have formed such as the Lone Parents Association, DADS and the Family Law Reform Party—is an indication that there is growing distress from marital break‐up. The purpose of this legislation at all times—and into the future—is to move these matters out of the legal system and into a social and community context, into alternative dispute resolution and into support for future families from both parents.

It is not a male or female issue. Quite frequently these days, the female is the paying parent and, quite frequently, it is the female of a second or third marriage who is wearing the consequences of prior relationships. These things, in light of a changing society and very mobile family relationships, are going to continue to be part of society. Our definition of family continually needs to evolve and we continually need to update legislation to make it reflect the times.

Most paying parents have a very sincere attitude to their children. They want to have a continuing relationship with the children and they spend an enormous amount of money on their children when they have access. Child support needs to take into account a number of payments that paying parents are already making.

This act goes some way to delivering, for the paying parent, a feeling that their concerns are being listened to by government, that there is some hope in the future before their children turn 18 when they can mend the fences with their previous spouse and get to some cordial social relationship where they can, between themselves, make payments to each other.

It also gives the parents a chance to choose how they are going to pay for their child support. By voluntarily paying it to the parent with custodial obligations, it takes the fault away from the paying spouse. They then feel that their personal affairs are not aired in public with their employers by having their wages garnisheed or by having to do battle in that adversarial manner with the Child Support Agency. They feel more adult about getting on with their responsibilities to their children and their previous relationships, whilst still leaving room for them to get on with new relationships and family matters.

This bill is a very important step. It certainly does not go far enough, and the committee is working to move in the direction of answering all concerns in this area, both for the custodial spouse and for the paying parent. With that, I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I will spend the first couple of minutes relating a story that came to me today. It is not particularly related to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1), but it is certainly related to the issue of what this bill addresses. To those present tonight who are mums and dads—and I stress that what I am going to say to you, as the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) said, is not a male or female issue; it can happen to either parent—you might understand what I am going to say to you.

SPEECH.PARA: One of my staff, in fact, has separated from his spouse and there has been a terrible problem in that separation. My staff member lives on Magnetic Island so has to catch a ferry from the mainland to the island. The other spouse, in fact, spends quite a lot of time on Magnetic Island and catches a similar ferry. There is a child of that relationship and just on the weekend that particular spouse and child were on the ferry when the person who works for me also got on that ferry.

When the person got on the ferry the young child who is a young man of about four years of age saw his father and said, `Daddy. Daddy,' and basically called to him to come. So the father in that situation went to his son, took him in his arms and hugged him, and spent some time with his son. When the ferry got to the other end of the journey to Magnetic Island, the other spouse went straight to the police and reported the father for stalking and for attempting to abduct his son.

What a sad situation this would be. How you would abduct your son on a ferry I do not know. Those of us who have a loving relationship and who have sons and daughters can understand how a dad would feel in that situation. I do not know why this is happening. In my own marriage I have a wonderful relationship. I have a wonderful son and daughter. But how can we in our society today have a situation where dads or mums cannot see their sons or daughters when they should see them. What is wrong with us? What is wrong with our society? At the moment I feel the way the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) did. I did not intend this, but it is just how I feel. Why do parents have to separate? Why do they have to use each other in this way. No‐one cares about the kids. Thank God, Margaret, Mark and I and my daughter, Kylie, are a loving family.

I should get back to the text of my speech now. When I became a member of parliament I was astonished by the level of public concern regarding family law and child support issues. Often the two are confused which does not help matters. It did not take me long to get an indication of the depth of the problems that I was being confronted with from day one in my term as a member of the federal parliament. Even now, some 14 months down the track, it is still difficult to know where to begin addressing the problems my constituents bring to me. I see on a daily basis examples of how the current CSA system is not working. My Townsville office staff have lost count of the number of times that they have taken calls from women and men who have gone through the Family Court and the child support system and have come out the other end almost literally with nothing to live for.

It is heartbreaking to listen to grown men and women fall to pieces over the phone because they have not seen their children for months on end even though they are legally entitled to see them, or because they have not received any child support payments. I can understand why people talk openly about living only from one day to the next and seriously contemplating on a daily basis taking their lives. As much as I admire the people who work in the Townsville Child Support Agency, they can only operate under the system we helped set up for them and we know that, while the system has vastly improved over recent years, it is still not working.

I will support the changes presented in this bill, but I think everyone who has spoken on this bill recognises the need to go much further in terms of legislative changes. Half‐hearted attempts to change the system will not really achieve the change for the better we all know the system desperately needs. We all know family breakdown can turn into a very bitter and nasty affair. One party blames the other; they both get lawyers; both parties seem willing to do or say anything to get custody of children, and so it goes.

We might have to be mindful that, when we do try to change the way in which the CSA operates, we may change it for the benefit of one party, but to the detriment of the other, be they custodial or non‐custodial. We also need to be mindful of the fact that, in dealing with cases of family breakdown, you simply are not going to be able to please 100 per cent of the people 100 per cent of the time. We need to weigh up the pros and cons of legislative change and act to make the CSA as workable and as fair as possible. My fear is that, if we set out to please everybody, we will end up with half‐hearted reforms that will not go to the root of the problems members and senators see walking through their doors—week in, week out.

By far and away, the largest number of Townsville CSA related complaints I receive come from the non‐custodial parents. I receive, as I am sure every other member of this House does, many complaints from custodial parents about the Child Support Agency. More often than not those complaints are from women who are faced with having to make repayments because the child support paying father's income has changed. This often places custodial parents in a very difficult financial position.

However, in between his income changing and the administrative process recognising the change in income status occurring, the paying parent is still paying at a higher rate than he can afford. The receiving parent is at the same time being overpaid and running up a bill she will have to repay once the system catches up with the change in the paying parent's income.

This impacts on both parents, the custodial and the non‐custodial. I have seen, on more than one occasion, mothers come into my Townsville office in tears because they have just received a letter telling them that they have to pay back a considerable sum of money because of overpayments. In cases I have personally come across, quite often the single mother is not in a position where she can repay this money, certainly not in one lump sum and certainly not in the time indicated on the letter that she receives.

The proposed amendment will reduce the incidence of overpayments to persons receiving child support which currently arise because of the retrospective effect of an income estimate election. It will better reflect a payer's future capacity to pay because the amount payable will only be changed for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. It will reduce the level of child support arrears that may arise when payers spend amounts refunded to them as overpayments, but later do not have the funds to meet their advised ongoing child support liability. I certainly hope that this will be the case.

The explanatory memorandum further states, in relation to the use of election where income changed, the parents paying child support will still pay the correct amount for the year based on the income estimate. If overpayments are made, they will reduce the remaining child support liability for the remaining part of the year. Similarly, underpayments will be offset evenly throughout the remainder of the year and this is a very good position to be in. These are good measures, which will take some pressure off the child support receiving parents, who instead of being faced with repaying overpayments, will instead have their repayments reduced for a period of time to reflect the relative size of the overpayment.I think that such a change will be easier for child support recipients to manage.

I have in the parliament today a petition of 1,300 signatures calling on reforms for the Child Support Agency and family law system. This petition was compiled by Mr Laurie Chalker in my electorate. Mr Chalker was due to start a marathon run from Townsville to Canberra last month in protest at the way in which the CSA and the family law systems do not work. Unfortunately, his run had to be cancelled. Had he been able to travel all the way to Canberra collecting signatures, this group of signatures would have been but a small fraction of what Laurie would have been able to collect. That brings me to another point.

All the people with CSA problems who walk through our individual electorate doors are but pieces of a very large jigsaw. The fact that so many members have spoken on this bill, and intend to speak on this bill, is evidence that Child Support Agency problems are not confined to just Queensland, Tasmania or Victoria. As elected representatives speaking on this bill we are individual pieces in a much larger jigsaw. I am the Herbert piece; Bruce Billson is the Dunkley piece; Mr McClelland is the Barton piece, and so on.

Individually, we may just be one voice representing one small part of Australia. But, if you take us collectively, all the small pieces add up to form a very large picture. That picture is of the mums and dads, and most importantly of all the children, caught up in family breakdown as they are crying out for change and reform.

It was only last week I was visited by a constituent, in this case a custodial parent, and it was a lady. She said, `Mr Lindsay, I've just received a bill for $2,000 that I must pay because the Child Support Agency has overpaid me. I've spent that money in the last six months, I've spent it on my children. I run a very tight financial position but I now have this bill that I must pay. How do I pay it?' That is what we are dealing with tonight. These are the sorts of things that the government and the opposition, in a bipartisan way, need to be mindful of and need to do something about.

I have certainly been very active in working on the government members' Child Support Agency subcommittee because I believe that we have a responsibility as members of this parliament to try to correct the wrongs that exist currently in the system. I can understand the impatience to have these wrongs corrected. Since the recommencement of the parliamentary sittings I have been telling my constituents that we must make changes to the legislation, and what we are dealing with tonight is part of that. It is now June; we are still going. The worst part about it is that no‐one is really disagreeing with what we are trying to do, whether it be on the opposition side or on the government side.

I hope that together we can do something that will be for the benefit of those families who have been split in unfortunate circumstances. While tonight's legislative changes are relatively small, I find it a bit disconcerting that we simply cannot push it through because while we talk and adjourn, and talk and adjourn, people's lives are being adversely affected. I certainly hope that we can get support tonight for this bill. I invite all of my colleagues to support it, as I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak this evening on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I think we all know the philosophy behind the Child Support Agency. That philosophy is that if you bring a child into the world then you take responsibility for that child, whether your relationship with your partner continues or not. Too often in the past husbands, and de facto husbands, deserted their wives and left their children to the tender mercies of the state. It is not fair that the taxpayers of Australia should pay for the irresponsibility of those fathers, or for that matter those mothers, who for one reason or another desert their children, yet may well have the means to support them, totally or in part.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Child Support Agency was brought in to correct this anomaly. It depended on an order from the court or a percentage payment levied on the non‐custodial parent to support his or her children. It was collected by an agency within the taxation department. All those things are quite appropriate mechanisms but I do not think the original system took sufficient note of the human dimension of this problem. Such a system depends on goodwill and where that is absent there can be a lack of equality or empowerment. What I mean by that is that both parties initially, at the time when arrangements are made or need to be modified, should be able to represent their case in an equal and unfettered way. But quite often we see the situation where one party has legal aid and the other party has not. That of itself I think leads to quite an imbalance in the outcome.

I suppose that—as most do when they come into this job as a member of parliament—I felt that the responsibility to the CSA and the matter of custody and access were separate and distinct issues. After four years in the job I do not believe that any longer. In fact, I believe the diametrical opposite. Regardless of what previous parliaments have said, regardless of what my own party or the Labor Party have said, I have come inexorably to the conclusion that those two things are linked.

I believe that the custodial parent—the one in receipt of child support—has both a financial and custodial advantage. If this is not exercised with equanimity and natural justice a gross distortion and disadvantage occurs to the non‐custodial parent. For example, where a custodial parent says, `Yes, under the terms of the arrangement made by the court you can have the children for the school holidays but you will have to pay the airfares,' which might be quite considerable, what that often does is deprive the non‐custodial parent of the short number of weeks—two, four or six weeks a year—that that parent might have the children; it deprives the parent of the ability to give them a decent and meaningful holiday; and it deprives them of the opportunity to create a relationship with the children, albeit over a very short period.

Perhaps if the custodial parent is totally manipulative they might put it on the non‐custodial parent, even over that short period, to provide the children with new clothes, school clothes for the coming year or warm clothes if there is a climatic change. In other words, the kids become a sort of bargaining chip. They become collateral in the relationship. I am deeply saddened when I see non‐custodial parents, generally the fathers—and I do not say that with any sexist overtones whatsoever; it is generally the fathers—deprived of a meaningful relationship with their children.

I believe this could be addressed very easily, as indeed the recognition of the interrelationship between custody and access on one hand and maintenance on the other would confirm. I feel that on those occasions where the non‐custodial parent is in control of the children, whether the maintenance payments be voluntary or court established, the maintenance payment should be suspended for the non‐custodial parent. In other words, if the non‐custodial parent is taking care of the children during that period, then the equivalent of the fees should go to them.

It could be argued that the custodial parent has responsibilities over and above that in the home—electricity, rates, rent and so on—that continue whether the children are there or not and that perhaps there could be some formularisation of this on a one‐third/two‐thirds basis. In principle, I think that should be the case. During times of voluntarily agreed or court established access, the non‐custodial parent should not have to pay any form of maintenance, or perhaps only a limited amount to cover the ongoing running costs of the home.

This would be a discipline on manipulative custodial parents. A person might be using the kids as a weapon against the non‐custodial parent. She might be making it as hard as possible for him to have the kids, saying things like, `I'm going to make sure that he pays the fares and buys the kids warm clothes—I'm going to make it as difficult as possible for him.' Or she might say, `I'm going to say that the kids have got the flu and they can't come for four weeks; they can only come for two.'

In that situation, whatever the court or the voluntary agreement determined in terms of access would be invoked. For the period that was laid down in that agreement or that court access, the payments by the non‐custodial parent to the custodial parent would be suspended. I think that would solve a lot of problems very simply and very effectively.

If we are sincere about this, if we are fair dinkum that the welfare of the children should be the dominant feature of these relationships, then they cannot be used as collateral; they cannot be used as bargaining chips. I have heard of some horrific cases where fathers have waited for years to see their kids and, because of personal animosity between the mother and the father, the mother decides that she is going to put every possible barrier in the way of the father.

That sometimes spills over into even more vindictive activities. It is sad, too, that some sections of the legal fraternity are not lilywhite in this matter. There is a system in vogue at present, if the lawyers I speak to are any measure of the activity, that says that when a person is in a disadvantageous situation in a custody hearing, regardless of whether her ex‐spouse is violent or not, regardless of whether he has been showing animus towards the wife or not, a restraining order is taken out against him—not because he has done anything wrong, but because that will place the custodial parent in an advantageous position in the court hearing.

What is even worse—and this appals me right to my very core—is that quite often the charge is made that the father has sexually molested the children. Over the last four years, an increasing number of non‐custodial parents—in nearly all cases fathers—have come to me as white as a sheet saying, `I have never had any criminal conviction of any sort against me in my life. Now I am accused of molesting my children. I can no longer see them, except under supervision'—or in some cases not at all—`because of the charge made by my former spouse.'

It is a shocking and deliberate evil that is perpetrated that destroys the relationship between the non‐custodial parent and the children. The children, of course, know it is false, but society does not, and it places all the people in the chain—the Family Court, the bailiffs, the police and all those that get involved in these activities—in a horrendous position.

I have seen this in the case of a constituent in my electorate—and I repeat this in many of these speeches because I cannot get it out of my mind. When the actual court cases for custody and separation were going on, his wife received legal aid, whereas he hitchhiked on semitrailers some 1,000 kilometres or more from my electorate to Sydney. He went into court unrepresented. His former wife went into court with, on one occasion, a solicitor and two barristers. Despite this, he made a very good fist of it. The wife perjured herself on numerous occasions and got custody of the children, claiming to take them to a new relationship with her parents in western New South Wales. Within a month she was in a de facto relationship in North Queensland.

I saw that father with his limited resources do everything he could to regain those children. He had lost his home, a very successful business, and access to his children. But his wife used her position quite unconscionably and finally he was able to bring her to court in North Queensland for defiance of the custody arrangements in contempt of the Family Court. In the course of that particular case she argued—by the way, without any disclosure of this prior to the case—that some 11 years earlier he had molested her sister. On the basis of that charge, on what was probably the penultimate case in that custody hearing, that father from that day to this did not see his kids except under supervision.

I just find it appalling. But what is even worse is that, on the basis of this charge, the New South Wales police have charged him with interfering with that girl 11 years earlier. It is not for me to go into that case because it is before the courts but I just want to show you one of the extreme cases of the disintegration of a family. At the end of the day, what was the separation all about? Was it not for a better life for each of them and for the kids? What have they all ended up with: total and utter misery and the kids not knowing whether they are coming or going.

I think in the time that is available to me I would like to say something about second families. Many speakers have spoken of them. The Child Support Agency recognises that when there is a break‐up the children of the custodial parent often enter a new relationship. Sometimes it is one of great opulence and wealth and quite often the non‐custodial parent, already deprived of his children, finds a new relationship. Sometimes that relationship involves the children of his new partner—his stepchildren. But they are receiving no child support from their father or their non‐custodial parent because, perhaps, he was a waster, or a pensioner. Perhaps he was not in a position to pay any maintenance payments and for that reason the children of that second family, and the whole family, live at a gross disadvantage.

I believe that what we have to do is not have these ironclad rules but, rather, look at the whole family situation.
