Does anyone seriously pretend that when the custodial parent goes into an opulent relationship and gets maintenance payments from the previous, non‐custodial parent, the payments are going to be divvied up between the children and the stepchildren strictly in accordance with the way the father pays maintenance? Of course not. All the kids are going to be treated equally—and so they should be. But when you come back to the other family, the second family of the non‐custodial parent, quite often there is no wealth, and there is no adjusting mechanism made available.

I also believe that we need a more effective way of being able to alter arrangements. I had a case where a wife went off the rails mentally, claimed that she had separated from her husband, received maintenance payments for some years, and had them sent to a false address. It was a very clever scam, actually. It was not until her husband noticed how his tax refund cheques were falling and queried, on the third year, how he could lose the $4,000 refund he was expecting that he discovered it. They said, `You are separated from your wife.' He said, `No I am not.' He subsequently did separate from her. But during that period it was established by statutory declarations, by declarations from neighbours, that during the period for which this huge Child Support Agency bill had accumulated they had indeed not been separated. In fact, he had not been out of the family home for more than three nights in the whole period.

When I put that whole case to the Child Support Agency—and admittedly it was before the previous inquiry that we had in the last parliament, so I imagine things have improved, but it illustrates the point—there was no automatic adjustment. He was told, `There is nothing we can do about that. You will have to take it back to the court.' Where there is clear evidence like that, why put the whole system to that financial burden? In an instance like that, I think there should be something in provincial cities. Perhaps if we had Child Support Agency magistrates who would sit in the magistrate's court in the main provincial cities, they could hear these matters quickly and issue an order varying the regulations or the arrangements, rather than taking the whole business back through the Family Court. Surely something like that would be preferable.

I have only touched on a few points tonight, but I think they are very important points. As I said before, if we are fair dinkum about the welfare of the children, if we are fair dinkum about people who have separated in a supposedly non‐fault environment being able to rebuild their lives, then what we have to do is get this system right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most members in this House, I have found that the statistics in my electorate office show that by far the largest number of inquiries, and the most emotional and most time consuming, relate to the Child Support Agency. Nobody in my office, including me, was in any way qualified to be able to deal with some of the problems and concerns that have come into the office. I must say that I have quickly learnt to be able to give some words of wisdom to some of the unfortunate victims of this particular government bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Those words of wisdom are: no matter what you think of your partner, no matter how much you dislike your partner, go out and talk to your partner, find some sort of common ground and strike a deal, because the moment you walk away and look for a third party, that being the Child Support Agency, you are guaranteed to lose. Unfortunately, that is the reality of it; unfortunately also, with human nature, with the anger and bitterness associated with separation and a tug of war to try to inflict some sort of emotional gain through the children, it is not at all possible in most cases.

Although, like any thinking Australian, I agree with the concept behind the child support scheme that parenthood has its price and responsibilities regardless of the state of a marriage and that taxpayers should not bear the burden of failed marriages, after the relatively short time that I have spent as a member, it seems obvious to me that the administration of the child support scheme has gone dramatically off the rails. Legislation before the House in this bill is aimed at correcting some minor flaws encountered in the scheme and I commend those changes to the House. But this legislation needs to go much further than these changes. It is my belief that the whole operation of the child support scheme needs to be revisited in the name of fairness to all.

The question needs to be asked: what is the agenda driving this scheme and the agency that enforces it? Yet it has become readily apparent to me—and dare I say to the majority of members of this House—that the whole soul and structure of the child support scheme is in need of a dispassionate and all‐encompassing review, with a new, fresh, fair and rational approach to be taken.

BREAK.PARA: Problems with the child support service were of such an intense and urgent nature that late last year I had to convene a child support forum in Cairns, the main population centre in my electorate, which attracted over 70 participants. One of the problems facing the victims of the current child support scheme that came out of this forum and from the electorate office inquiries is that it would appear that the whole core of the problem can probably be best addressed by the vision statement of the Lone Fathers Association of Australia. That is that all parties in the divorce situation, including the non‐custodial parent, enjoy a fair and equitable distribution of financial resources emanating from a child support scheme and fair and equitable access to the children involved. Disregarding for the moment the attitudinal problems emanating from the CSA staff in their dealings with non‐custodial parents, the two primary problems seem to be in the assessment levels of child‐care contributions and the tax treatment of the CSS payments by contributing parents—the accountability of the money paid to the custodial parents through the scheme.

Let me make one point very clear. In most of the dealings my office has had with non‐custodial parents in the child support cases, there is absolutely no argument that a rational and reasonable level of contribution must be made towards the upkeep of children of failed marriages. Most non‐custodial parents accept this fact and willingly accept the concept of maintenance.

The problem is the methodology upon which the CSS is based and its enactment by the Child Support Agency. Firstly, on the assessment level, currently the formula used by the CSA is 18 per cent of gross wages for the first child, rising to 26 per cent of gross for five or more children. A major problem is in the use of the gross wage for the assessment purposes. The net effect of this payment to the average non‐custodial parent can be as high as a third to half more in real dollar terms than those percentages reflect on paper.

The government can take a major initiative in fairness by adjusting the formula to either a percentage of the net wage or by allowing the CSS payments to be tax deductible. The real effect of this arbitrary and unfair method of assessment is that many non‐custodial parents are leaving the work force and going onto the dole, simply because they feel that they are better off on the dole than having to pay exorbitant levels of support demanded of them under the current system.

If you have any doubts about this, you merely have to look at the number of non‐custodial parents in receipt of unemployment benefits. Approximately 30 per cent currently have taken that option and that is more than three times the national unemployment average. So, by default, government action to recover child support payments and reduce the burden on the taxpayer have the opposite effect of encouraging people onto the dole, thereby costing the taxpayer seven or eight times more than it would cost just to pay child support in addition to the sole parent pension. Talk about a hollow victory.

The problem with the assessment formula does not stop there. The anomaly between the level at which the Department of Social Security assesses the worth of the child and the level at which the CSA can assess the same child for higher income earners borders on the ridiculous. Standard DSS family payment for one child is $93.10 per fortnight. Yet a non‐custodial parent on a basic wage is forced to pay $186.70 per fortnight, slightly more than double what the government considers to be the worth of a child.

As the non‐custodial parent's income gets higher, the contribution level per child becomes commensurately more out of step with reality. There is no differentiation as to the age of the child or children. For example, a three‐year‐old qualifies the custodial parent for the same rate of payment as does a 13-year‐old, yet anyone would know that the cost of upkeep and education of a teenager is much higher than that of a toddler.

There is no doubt that the real problem is the escalating divorce rate in Australia. As a government, we are committed to a return to family values and it devolves upon us to look at some of the major issues that are contributing to the current high level of family break‐up in this nation. However, in the interim we have to look closely at how we can address the myriad of anomalies in the current child support scheme. Let us never lose sight of the real purpose of this scheme and our primary focus must always be on the innocent victims, the children. I must also acknowledge that in the majority of cases, both parents—and I repeat, both—have a deep love and intense interest in their children.

Accountability of CSA payments in the hands of the custodial parents also seems to be one of the major problems associated with the scheme. This is a major source of conflict that I and my staff are hearing from non‐custodial parents. The impression that they receive is that there is no accountability as to the direction of expenditure of CSA payments in the custodial parent's hands and that in many cases the money is used on expenditure totally unassociated with the care and upbringing of their child or children.

Another concern is that when the custodial parent has taken up with another partner in a de facto relationship and both parties work, it is not uncommon to find a non‐custodial parent reduced to poverty through a CSA ruling on maintenance while a custodial parent enjoys their own income, sometimes an income on a par with their ex‐spouse, as well as the income of their de facto. I have heard of cases where a custodial parent in a new family situation and earning well in excess of $100,000 a year is receiving substantial CSA payments from an ex‐spouse who is struggling to meet these payments, as well as having to cater for a new family on a single income.

Possibly we, as a government, should look at setting up within the CSA a trust situation where the custodial parent is allowed to draw down regular maintenance payments from the moneys contributed by non‐custodial parents for living costs and must account for all other major items of expenditure on the child or children for things such as education and other expenses.This would ensure that funds contributed by non-custodial parents are used exclusively for what they were intended, the maintenance and upbringing of the child.

Another major area of concern that has been brought to my attention from dealing with people involved in the child support scheme is the problem of child access. There seems to be no relationship between demands to pay CSA payments and the paying parent's right to access the child. The dogma of confidentiality is so entrenched in the bureaucrats at the Child Support Agency that non‐custodial parents are often hounded for payments of child support, even when the custodial parent is ignoring decisions from the Family Court as regards access to children. It should be a two‐way street. If the CSA is going to religiously enforce one law, the payment of child maintenance, then it should ensure that the other laws of a family nature are adhered to and that custodial parents abide by Family Court access decisions. I believe that this is only fair.

Let us turn to the Child Support Agency itself. There are major attitudinal problems within the CSA that need addressing urgently. There would appear to be a regime of arrogance in place that in talks with my colleagues I have found to be almost universal across Australia. Non‐custodial parents are treated in the main with contempt by the apparatchiks who staff this agency, which is totally contrary to the concept of a no fault divorce.

If there is to be more than easy access to the termination of marriage that seems to be the norm today, on the basis of no need to prove fault, then there should be no fault attributed to dealings with either the divorced or separated couple. This does not appear to be the case with the CSA. Almost every case that is brought to my office's attention includes an element of dissatisfaction with the attitudes of people in the CSA.

Besides problems of arrogance and assumed guilt, there seems to be no continuity of dealing with staff. Non‐custodial parents rarely speak to the same case officer twice and arbitrary decisions without any semblance of concern for the wellbeing of the non‐custodial parent, or in many cases for their new family, bring about hardships beyond the normal human compassion.

This goes both ways. It is not only the non‐custodial parent that suffers from the shortcomings of the CSA. There seems to be a regime within the CSA of taking the easy way out. I have a particular case in my electorate where a non‐custodial father, very well‐known around the town as being, if not a millionaire, verging on that asset level, has structured his affairs in such a way that he has managed to bring his child support payments down to a mere $30 a week, some $17 a week less than his estranged wife could get in family benefits, forcing his estranged wife to try and raise their daughter on something like $100 a week after mortgage payments.

Yet this gentleman has three booming businesses in Far North Queensland, a large and profitable painting business offshore, and a new one starting in Cairns. He lives in a $650,000 home in an exclusive beach suburb to which he recently added a $50,000 swimming pool and he recently bought his current girlfriend a $100,000 luxury motor car. You can see quite clearly that it goes both ways. I think this is another area that we have to look at very seriously, where people are able to conceal their income and, in doing so, are able to walk away from their commitment of contributing to payments for the upbringing of their children. It seems that, in that case, the CSA found it too hard to research this man's assets and income to realise that he has a very smart accountant and is conning the agency.

This government is in a unique position to put a new broom through much of the anti‐family legislation that we have inherited. I believe the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when he says that he wants to run a government that returns this nation to traditional family values that once made it a much more stable society than it is today after 13 years of social engineering. This bill is a small start to cleaning up some of the surface anomalies in the child support legi slation, but we certainly need to go much, much deeper. We need to go right to the heart of this act and bring to it fairness, accountability and justice for all concerned.

I am an active member of the recently established government backbench committee dealing with child support legislation, and I am certainly looking forward to changes that we hope will be introduced later this year. There are literally hundreds and thousands of Australians out there, both custodial and non‐custodial parents, who are haemorrhaging under the socially libertine attacks on the institution of marriage this act encourages.

They say that from acorns great oaks grow. I commend this bill to the House, primarily in the hope that it is a first small step in returning justice and fair treatment to what is one of the major social engineering failures of this and the previous decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Draper, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me much pleasure to speak in support of the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. Since being elected to represent the people of Makin in this place, I have received many requests for assistance in matters relating to child support and the Child Support Agency. It was a matter I raised in my first speech in the House.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of many constituent inquiries I have received on this issue, I have made numerous representations to the then Assistant Treasurer, Senator Jim Short and the current Assistant Treasurer, Senator Rod Kemp. They have, on each and every occasion, been willing to listen to my requests and have been extremely helpful in seeking a resolution to the particular problem I have been seeking to resolve on behalf of my constituents and, most importantly, their children.

As a result of representations from government members, me included, the Assistant Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, have established a committee to investigate suggested changes to the child support system. As a member of this committee, I appreciate the opportunity to bring the concerns of my constituents directly to the ministers responsible for the operation of the agency and related services.

I place on record my appreciation of the fine work being done by the staff of the Child Support Agency in Adelaide, South Australia. Their work can sometimes be very difficult and distressing, but I have always found them ready and willing to help to the best of their ability, even though the outcomes are not always what both parents would wish.

The establishment of the Child Support Agency has had a significant effect on the number of non‐custodial parents who now pay child support. Prior to its introduction, it is estimated that only one in three non‐custodial parents was paying child support. This compares with the current situation where 56 per cent of all collect cases pay child support each and every month. Furthermore, surveys that have been taken suggest that about 85 per cent of registered private collection cases pay regularly. This means that around 65 per cent of registered payers now make regular payments to support their children. These figures illustrate the general success of the agency in ensuring that both parents contribute towards the upbringing of their child or children.

Despite this, however, we recognise that there are problems and inequities within the current system. Over the last three years, the number of cases being dealt with by the Child Support Agency has increased by around 50,000 per year, and this is expected to continue. At the end of last year, there were 247,000 collect cases in the system and a further 164,000 registered private collection cases.

The Howard government's 1996‐97 budget recognised the necessity of reforming aspects of the system and provided additional resources to the Child Support Agency. As a result of the reforms already made by the government, child support collections increased by $36 million in the 12 months between December 1995 and December 1996, and the amount of child support debt was reduced. Some 80 per cent of total child support liability was collected and distributed to custodial parents, and the number of payers having their arrears directly deducted from their wages increased by more than 4,000.

There is still a need for further improvement, as my constituents will testify, but I am sure that all Australians would be pleased with the progress so far. The issue of the repayment of overpayments by custodial parents has been raised with me on several occasions. On one occasion, a distressed constituent contacted me after receiving a letter from the Child Support Agency requesting her to repay a sum of money.

The constituent had already used the money to provide her two children with the opportunity to visit their grandparents in Victoria. She could not afford to travel with them and had had to scrimp and save to provide them with enough money for the trip. The letter from the agency was a very unpleasant shock to her and she did not know what to do. Thankfully, assistance was provided and her two children got to see their grandparents, but this highlights one of the problems which currently exists and, I am pleased to say, it is being addressed in this bill.

As members would be aware, child support assessments are calculated using the income tax returns of the payer for the previous two years. If the payer feels that his or her income for the current year will be more than 15 per cent less than previously estimated, he or she can have their child support payments reassessed. This estimate affects the child support payments from the beginning of the financial year, meaning that the custodial parent may have to refund money which has already been paid.

To illustrate this point, I wish to mention another case which was brought to my attention by one of my constituents. On this occasion, the custodial parent had been overpaid and was required to repay the money. However, the estimate given by the payer had been incorrect and he had, in fact, earned more than his estimate. The result was that my constituent had to pay back all of the amount she was overpaid and then would receive back part of this after the adjustment was made for the payer's incorrect estimate. She could not see the logic in this and, frankly, nor could I.

This bill changes the way in which overpayments are recovered. A parent will no longer be required to refund money already paid. Overpayments will be recovered by reducing the non‐custodial parent's payments for the year. Underpayments will also be made up over the period of the year, rather than all at once.

It will still be a requirement for the correct and total amount of money for the year to be paid, but these changes will mean that far fewer custodial parents will be required to repay overpaid amounts of child support. This measure will also lead to a more accurate assessment of the non‐custodial parent's future capacity to pay, because the amount payable will only be changed for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. The level of child support arrears should also be reduced as a result of these changes.

Another improvement that will be implemented on the passage of this bill relates to the preferred method of payment by payers of their child support obligations. Currently, many payments are deducted directly from the non‐custodial parent's wages by his or her employer and sent to the Child Support Agency. I know of a number of my constituents who are distressed by this lack of control over their own finances and who resent the fact that their employers are forced to become involved in a private matter.

The changes in this bill will allow non‐custodial parents to make payments directly to the Child Support Agency without the involvement of his or her employer. This is in line with the recommendations of the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues—as is much of this bill. We must give credit to the work done by that committee.

Naturally, this change to allow non‐custodial parents to directly pay the agency is subject to the approval of the registrar. The registrar must be satisfied that the parent will pay on time. Custodial parents can be reassured by the fact that the registrar will be able to reverse the decision to allow direct payment if payments are not made on time.

BREAK.PARA: A payer parent who has had his or her application for direct payment rejected must wait two months before applying again for this method of payment. Similarly, a payer parent who has failed to make regular payments on time, using the direct payment method, may have the employer deductions reintroduced and must wait six months before applying again for the direct payment method.

These provisions safeguard the custodial parent, whilst giving the opportunity to non‐custodial parents to make regular direct payments to the Child Support Agency. Furthermore, this measure is in line with the government's stated aim of supporting small business. By providing the option of direct payments by the payer parents, the responsibility and associated compliance costs to employers will be reduced.

A further aspect of this bill that will please non‐custodial parents, in particular, is the provision to amend the Family Law Act 1975 to enable the court to consider future child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings. This will apply even without an administrative assessment under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

I have received many representations from non‐custodial parents who feel that their child support arrangements are unfair and do not take into full account their financial position. The anger and emotion of some of these parents illustrates the need to ensure fairness and equity in dealing with issues relating to child support and family law.

There have been cases where there has been no child support assessment applied for when the custodial parent has applied for child support arrears after the property settlement has been determined. In such cases, the child support liability has not been taken into consideration, to the detriment of the payer parent. Amendments in this bill will allow payer parents to have these future child support obligations recognised and taken into account by the Family Court before the settlement of property and spousal maintenance. This is both fair and equitable, and in line with the Howard government's commitment to the implementation of positive reforms to child support arrangements.

I must comment on the breathtaking audacity of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) during his contribution to this debate. The member for Werriwa has suddenly become a latter day champion of reform in the area of child support arrangements. Never mind that, in 13 years of Labor, nothing was done to make the system fairer; never mind that the thousands of Australians who held genuine grievances concerning this matter were ignored by Labor ministers and by an unsympathetic Labor government.

I know the stories, and I have seen the heartbreak caused by the callous attitude that Labor has towards people. But we now have the member for Werriwa whingeing and complaining that the Howard coalition government is not doing enough. The honourable member moves amendments designed to play politics with people's sensitivities, yet he does not recognise the absolute failure of his own previous Labor government to do anything to improve the system when they had the chance.

We now have substantial reforms before us which will help to make child support arrangements fairer and more equitable. The member for Werriwa ought to reflect on that. He ought to remember that the improvements are taking place under the Howard coalition government. This government has proven willing to listen and act on matters relating to child support. I am very pleased to be able to bring the concerns of my constituents directly to the minister responsible. The establishment of a government committee on the Child Support Agency has enabled government members to voice the concerns of their constituents and work on finding practical solutions.

There were over 6,000 public submissions to the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. This reflects the very real need for the reforms contained within this bill, and for an ongoing process of reform to further improve the system of child support.

I believe in the need for further considered reform to ensure even greater fairness and equity. As I said in my first speech in the House, many constituents feel that the child support formula is unfair because it is calculated on taxable income minus exempt income, rather than on net income, which is the amount of money that the non‐custodial parent has to live on in real terms. I said at that time, and I say it again today, that I will continue to work towards a fairer system for both custodial and non‐custodial parents in my electorate of Makin and Australia‐wide, for the benefit of all children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence by thanking many members for their contributions to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. In effect, all members from both sides of the parliament have supported the contents of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The number of speakers to this bill indicates the amount of interest in parliament with the operation of the child support scheme. Firstly, I would like to respond to the amendment moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) on behalf of the opposition. For obvious reasons, the government will not be supporting this amendment. As the member for Makin (Mrs Draper) has very adequately and eloquently said, the opposition—the member for Werriwa in this case—are moving amendments when they had 13 years to do something about this issue. It is gross hypocrisy to come here and criticise us when we have been in government for only 15 months. We are responding, and we are responding in a very significant way.

For the record, the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues reported in November 1994. That committee made 163 recommendations for change to the Child Support Agency and to the scheme in general. At the time that the coalition government took office, more than 100 of the recommendations from this committee had not been responded to.

Those that were addressed by the previous government were largely administrative. The recommendations left to this government, not surprisingly, are more substantive and more complex. For the most part, the remaining recommendations from the report of the joint select committee involve complex issues of equity between separated parents, their children and the Commonwealth.

As many members have indicated, the government is giving careful consideration to the operation of the scheme and, in particular, to the remaining recommendations from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. This is in stark contrast to the previous government. I note with interest the remarks made earlier this week by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), chair of the joint select committee, when speaking on his private member's bill in relation to this matter. He said:
. . . it never occurred to me that nearly three years would have elapsed and that only the easiest of the recommendations—53 in all—would have been tackled by my government—
the Labor government when they were in power—

and the present government and that the remaining more difficult policy issues would be and continue to be unresponded to . . . In fact, if I reflect on the three years, I am a little surprised that the caucus has never really had an opportunity to vote on these measures or any of the other recommendations.
That is from Hansard , 2 June, 1997.

This is the government's first legislative response to recommendations made by the joint select committee. The government recognises that this bill does not address the key issues of the joint select committee. However, the government does not believe that these commonsense reforms should await consideration of the somewhat more substantial issues raised by the joint select committee and many others in the community. Nothing says more about the priority given to child support by the previous government than the fact that the first legislative response to the committee had to await the advent of a coalition government to be introduced.

The bill amends the child support legislation to bring it into line with the provisions and concepts of the Social Security Act 1991, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Each of these acts has undergone change over the last few years without at the time making the necessary consequential changes to child support legislation.

The bill amends the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 to adopt the thrust of recommendation 124 of the joint select committee on the use of income estimates. This amendment will allow estimates for the most part to have a prospective effect only. This will reduce the incidence of overpayments to persons receiving child support by removing the retrospective effect of the current income estimate provisions. The bill amends the Child Support (Registration Collection) Act 1988 to enable parents who pay child support to elect to pay directly to the register. This amendment adopts recommendations 55 through to 57 of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. It reduces the level of intrusiveness of the child support scheme where payers voluntarily comply with their child support obligations and over time may reduce the administrative and compliance costs of the scheme.

The amendment provides a better balance between the need for regular financial support for children of separated parents and the rights of parents to privacy. The bill also amends the Family Law Act 1975 to allow the courts to take into account the child support liability of a person in property and spousal maintenance proceedings, even where a child support assessment has not been issued. The amendment responds to recommendations 156 of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues.

The reforms proposed in the bill are responsible. They remove some significant and frequent causes for complaint from payers and recipients of child support. They are, to use the words of the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) `human and responsive reforms'. They represent a small step in responding to the outstanding recommendations from the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues and I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he discuss with the Minister for Health and Family Services and the Attorney‐General convening a National Drug Summit featuring State and Territory Health Ministers and Attorneys‐General, police and judicial authorities, experts in the field of drug and heroin dependency, and representatives from social welfare and religious bodies in order to discuss new approaches to obtaining a national solution to the heroin problem; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I consider that it would be wasteful of resources and unnecessary to convene a national drug summit at this point in time, for two reasons.

Firstly, an independent evaluation of the National Drug Strategy has just been completed. The evaluation addressed the advisory and wider consultative mechanisms in place through the National Drug Strategy. The evaluation team, led by Professor Eric Single of the Department of Preventive Medicine and Biostatistics in the University of Toronto and Professor Tim Rohl of the Australian Graduate School of Police Management in Charles Sturt University, received written submissions and held discussions with expert researchers, service providers, community groups and consumer organisations. The report of the evaluation will be discussed by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council and the Australian Health Minister's Conference at their respective meetings in July 1997. These meetings are expected to look at the future directions of the National Drug Strategy and particularly the incorporation of broader consultative mechanisms as recommended by the evaluators. If such a broad consultative approach can be achieved, a national drug summit will not be necessary.

Secondly, the "heroin problem" is complex and could not be resolved by a single summit. We need to develop and maintain a multi‐faceted, national, strategic approach, such as that being pursued through the Illicit Drugs Expert Working Group (a subcommittee of the National Drug Strategy Committee), in conjunction with ongoing public debate and consultation. This underlines the importance of a broad consultative mechanism within the framework of the National Drug Strategy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Do the uniform national gun laws established in 1996 affect the sale, ownership and use of automatic pistols and hand‐guns; if so how; if not, will he initiate talks with State and Territory leaders to establish tougher new laws covering the sale, ownership and use of automatic pistols and hand‐guns similar to the laws brought in by the British Government following the Dunblane school massacre; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Handguns have been very tightly regulated in Australia since the 1920s. Their ease of concealment and potential for misuse in criminal activity or accidents has led to the general acceptance that they should be subject to the most stringent controls. Consequently all Australian jurisdictions have required handguns to be registered and owners to be licensed.

Tests for private access to handguns are so tight in every jurisdiction that, with very few exceptions, they can only be used for the provision of professional security services and competition target shooting.

The Nationwide Agreement on Firearms, agreed by all Australian governments on 10 May 1996, places the toughest possible controls on the possession, use, sale, resale and transfer of all firearms, including handguns.

Applicants for handgun licences must prove both a "genuine reason" for owning, possessing or using a handgun as well as a "genuine need' for that particular firearm. Applicants must also obtain a permit to acquire a handgun, which is subject to a waiting period of at least 28 days to enable appro priate checks on the applicant by the licensing/registration authorities.

The 1996 Agreement also agreed on minimum standards for the security and storage of handguns. These require that handguns be stored in a locked, steel safe with a thickness to ensure it is not easily penetrable, bolted to the structure of a building, and all ammunition must be stored in locked containers separate from any firearms. Sales of firearms, including by mail order, must be conducted only by or through licensed firearms dealers. Mail order sales of handguns must be in accordance with prescribed safety requirements.

Most of the measures in the 1996 Agreement have been implemented by State and Territory governments. However, the Commonwealth Government has also taken steps to control the availability of certain handguns by amending the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to include as prohibited items any handguns that have a fully automatic firing capability or resemble a sub‐machine gun, machine pistol or soft air handgun.

The Government does not have current plans to re‐examine these stringent controls on the possession, use and sale of handguns, but in line with all firearms issues, there will be careful continuing monitoring.

(4) Did his parliamentary secretary during (a) discussions in the Senate or (b) public comments on the People's Constitutional Convention, make it clear that members of the public were invited to apply for appointment to the Convention; if so, (i) when and (ii) what was the exact phrasing of his invitation; if not, why not.

(5) Did the Government advertise in the media that members of the public were invited to apply for appointment to the People's Constitutional Convention; if so, (a) when, (b) in which section of the media and (c) was the closing date for applications included as part of the advertisement; if no advertisements were taken out, why not.
(6) What was the closing date for members of the public to apply for appointment to the People's Constitutional Convention.
(7) How many applications from members of the public for appointment to the People's Constitutional Convention has the Government received as at 13 May 1997.
(8) What are the names of the (a) individuals and (b) public groups, associations or organisations, who have applied for appointment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The government will consider all nominations from members of the public for appointment to the Constitutional Convention.

(2) No general invitation was issued. However, members of the public made enquiries of my office, Senator Minchin's office and my department about participating in the Convention, both before and after Convention details were announced. Those who wished to do so were encouraged to nominate for appointment.

(3)‐(5) A public invitation was not seen as a necessary step in assembling a suitably diverse group from which to select the appointed delegates. However, the Government did write to office holders including the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, all Premiers and Chief Ministers, the President of the Australian Local Government Association and the heads of the Australian Republican Movement and the Australians for Constitutional Monarchy, inviting them to submit names for consideration.

(6) The Government will announce the appointed delegates before nominations close for the election of delegates to the Convention. Depending on passage of the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997, this announcement is, estimated to be in late June. As far as reasonably practical, nominations received before the decision is finalised and announced will be taken into consideration.
(7) Close to 700 individuals had been nominated as at 13 May 1997.

(8) Those submitting nominations either on their own behalf or on behalf of others would not have had any expectation that their nomination would be made public. In due course, as explained in the answer to (6) above, the Government will announce the names of the appointed delegates. Meanwhile I do not consider it appropriate to release names of nominees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What safeguards does the Government have in place to monitor the storage of uranium mine tailings and the transport of radioactive material.
(2) What is the annual cost to the Government of the monitoring activities.
(3) What is the annual cost to the Government of maintaining the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation and the Lucas Heights reactor.

(5) What will be the cost of decommissioning the Lucas Heights reactor and what plans does the Government have for the disposal of the radioactive buildings.
(6) What will be the cost of building a new reactor at Jervis Bay.
(7) How many cyclotrons are there in Australia and what medical isotopes do they produce.
(8) What medical isotopes are produced at Lucas Heights and what medical isotopes are imported into Australia.
(9) Where in inland Australia is the Government proposing to place a nuclear waste dump and how will nuclear waste be transported to that site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Nuclear Codes of Practice were central to the 1977 Commonwealth Government decision to mine and export uranium. Under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 (Nuclear Codes Act), three national codes of practice have been published based on international standards:
(i) Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1982) (`Waste Management Code');
(ii) Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1987) (`Radiation Protection Code'); and
(iii) Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances (1990) (`Transport Code').

The Codes provide for radiation safety in the mining and milling of radioactive ores and the transport of radioactive material. They have been developed on a federal consultative basis, with implementation of Code requirements remaining the responsibility of individual Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments under the Nuclear Codes Act. Administration of the Codes is the responsibility of the Department of Health and Family Services.

The Radioactive Waste Management Code requires development of a waste management program for operations involving the mining and milling of radioactive ores including uranium. The program must be approved by the competent authority. It also requires establishment of a monitoring program, to the satisfaction of the appropriate authority, prior to commencement of construction or development work at the mine or mill.

The Transport Code sets out strict conditions for the protection of both the public and workers from the effects of radiation during the transport of radioactive materials. Transport of radioactive materials and licensing of radioisotopes is generally handled by State/Territory Health departments in accordance with State/Territory regulations which incorporate Code requirements.

The safety of major shipments of Commonwealth radioactive material is regulated on a case by case basis by the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL), with the Nuclear Safety Bureau (NSB) providing advice. As of 1 July 1997 the NSB and ARL will be designated joint Competent Authorities for the purposes of regulating transport of Commonwealth‐owned radioactive material.

Monitoring the storage of uranium tailings and regulation of the safe transport of uranium is principally the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. However, due to the Commonwealth's involvement in uranium mining in the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth has a more direct role in these activities through the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS). The OSS was established to co‐ordinate and supervise measures for the protection and restoration of the environment of the Alligator Rivers Region (ARR) from the effects of uranium mining. These activities include monitoring the adequacy of tailings storage and the transport of uranium within the ARR.

From a physical security perspective, the Commonwealth has responsibilities under the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 for transport of fresh and irradiated nuclear fuel and uranium ore concentrates (yellowcake). Under this Act, a system of Permits has been established which requires permit holders to comply with prescriptions laid down by the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO). The requirements of ASO include the physical protection (security) levels to be applied to all movements of `nuclear material' i.e. uranium, thorium and plutonium. Details are laid down in the permits issued to relevant possessors of nuclear material e.g. ANSTO and the two operators of Australia's uranium mines.

(2) Where the Commonwealth has an interest in the above activities for example, from a physical security perspective, in relation to uranium mining in the ARR, and where radioactive material is Commonwealth owned, a number of Commonwealth agencies are involved as indicated above.

Since these activities are only a facet of the many activities undertaken by involved agencies it is not possible to attribute an annual cost. In addition, in relation to these activities, costs for certain services are recovered from companies in which case there is no net cost to the Commonwealth Government.
(3) The 1996‐97 Parliamentary appropriation for ANSTO was $63.65 million which includes funding for maintaining the Lucas Heights Research Reactor.

(4) Yes, research is conducted at the Lucas Heights reactor as well as at the other research facilities on the Lucas Heights site. Research is undertaken by ANSTO scientists, visiting international scientists, university staff and PhD students. The nuclear science and technology research conducted by these parties covers a number of areas including the environment, minerals processing, materials, nuclear safety, physics, biomedicine and health. Further details on the research undertaken by ANSTO can be found in the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Annual Report, 1995‐96. Research topics being conducted, using ANSTO facilities, by university staff and students can be found in the Australian Institute of Nuclear Science and Engineering (AINSE) Annual Report 1995. Both these documents are available to the public.

(5) The Government has not made a decision on the method of decommissioning for the Lucas Heights reactor. However, the 1993 Research Reactor Review (RRR) addressed this issue and broadly agreed with the approach to decommissioning proposed by ANSTO, which was to put the reactor under care and maintenance for 30 years and after this period of time make a decision whether to encapsulate the reactor, dismantle it, or extend the care and maintenance period. The estimated cost in the RRR for encapsulation after 30 years care and maintenance was $48.2 million and the estimated cost for dismantling after 30 years was $70.2 million.

The above costs were based upon the availability of a national facility to accept the radioactive waste generated from decommissioning. The Government is currently conducting a study to locate a national repository site for low‐level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste. Radioactive decommissioning wastes which are suitable for near‐surface disposal, will be disposed of at a national repository.

Long‐lived intermediate level (Category S) decommissioning wastes, that are not suitable for near‐surface disposal, could be stored at a national store pending deep disposal. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy advises that the small quantity of Category S waste produced by Australia would not, at present, justify construction of a deep disposal facility. Possible co‐location of a Category S store with a national near‐surface repository is being considered by the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee on Radioactive Waste Management.
(6) There is no proposal for the construction of a research reactor at Jervis Bay and no cost estimates have been made.

(7) There are two cyclotrons in Australia that are used for the production of medical isotopes. These are the National Medical Cyclotron (NMC), situated at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney and operated by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, and a smaller cyclotron at the Austin Hospital in Melbourne. (9) A site for a national repository for low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste has not yet been identified. A public report which will identify a preferred region from the eight regions identified in the 1994 Phase 2 report is expected to be issued later this year.

Radioactive waste will be transported to a national repository in accordance with strict requirements set out in the national Code of Practice on the Safe Transport of Radioactive Waste 1990 and relevant State/Territory requirements. The mode of transport will depend on where the repository is located and from where in Australia the radioactive waste is to be transported, as well as the quantity to be transported.
